PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned notes that the level of foreign ownership and control of Australian assets is of concern to many Australians.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) establish a register of foreign ownership.
(b) limit foreign ownership of real estate.
(c) control foreign investment in Australia so as to protect the national interest.
(d) increase the powers and resources of the Foreign Investment Review Board.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDS Commercial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners request that the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health cause to cease immediately the broadcasting of any AIDS commercials which have as their premise that the use of condoms makes casual sexual activities acceptable particularly amongst young adolescents because of the detrimental effect which such campaigns have upon the morals of our society.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(1) They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
(2) They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901 and each point depicting a State and the Territories of the Commonwealth.
(3) They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
(4) They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
(5) They are certain that any change to its form or to its acceptance as the sole Australian Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should ensure that the existing Australian National Flag should remain sacrosanct from change and remain the sole national flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Animal Patenting
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Australian Senate.
The undersigned citizens of Australia oppose the patenting of animals, and the processes for altering them. Animal patents would:

*compromise animal welfare, *allow genetic engineering companies to appropriate the fruits of centuries of selective breeding, *reduce biodiversity, and *further concentrate ownership of breeding stock. We note with concern that many applications for animal patents have been lodged with the Australian Patents Office and without your intervention they may soon be approved.
Therefore, please take all possible steps immediately to ensure that:
1. The Patents Office rejects all existing applications for animal patents and declines to accept any more.
2. The Senate amends the Patents Bill 1989 to prohibit the patenting of animals.
We urge the members of the Australian Senate to act on this petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Rainforests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of Australia. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that 219 hectares of reserved forest in the Apollo Bay water catchment forest in the Otway Rainforests, Victoria has been set aside as a flora reserve, but the rest of this catchment may be cleared for logging. Your petitioners humbly pray that this catchment may be wholly set aside as a National Estate to protect this unique rainforest.

PETITION.TITLE: Apartheid in South Africa
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That they are committed to the elimination of the abominable and inhuman system of apartheid in South Africa, as practised by the minority Government of that country, consistent with the promotion of human rights and civil liberties.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

Urge the Federal Government to formally request the South African Government to immediately cease the practice of apartheid, by repealing all laws and regulations relating thereto, and by the release of any political prisoners detained by virtue of such laws, and by any other means consistent with the human rights and civil liberties of all its people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister: in order to ensure that Australia's bid for the 1996 Olympics, which has the bipartisan support of both major political parties, is not sabotaged by Senator Walsh's intemperate statements, can the Minister assure the Senate in his capacity as representing the Prime Minister that the cost basis for the bid is sound? What assurances can the Minister now give that the industrial relations agreement signed in Victoria last week will ensure that the Olympic project is not hijacked by industrial disputation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I admit I had the opportunity of meeting with both members of the Melbourne Olympic Committee and members of the international committee over the weekend, and so I had the opportunity then to discuss a number of these things. First, let me say that as far as my colleague Senator Walsh is concerned, he can speak for himself; he frequently does. The Government is fully committed to the support of the Melbourne Olympic Games bid. The support of the Commonwealth Government has been manifest in a variety of ways but will be particularly displayed by the Prime Minister being a member of the bid team visiting Tokyo next week for the International Olympic Committee meeting.
—With the Leader of the Opposition.

—Yes, with the Leader of the Opposition-and I personally feel that the bid stands a very good chance of success. The Commonwealth Government agreed in January this year to the request from the Victorian Premier to provide $125m towards a world standard sporting complex at Albert Park in Melbourne should the bid be successful. That Albert Park sporting complex will be the major new facility for the Olympic Games if Melbourne is successful. Of course, the Melbourne Cricket Ground is being refurbished, but that is going to happen anyway. The decision to commit Commonwealth funds to the Melbourne Olympic Games bid in terms of the Albert Park project was subject to an interdepartmental committee decision which included the Department of Finance and the Australian Construction Services and other bodies reporting on the Victorian estimates of the costs and general economy of the Olympic Games bid. That IDC reported that the cost estimates were reasonable given the scope of the project. At this stage the Commonwealth has no other commitment to support the Melbourne Olympic Games bid-other than, I should add, a general enthusiasm on the part of most members of parliament and certainly the Government to support that bid.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Michael Baume also asked me about an industrial relations agreement signed in Victoria recently relating to cost escalation and time for completing projects such as the new facility at Albert Park. I am very confident that the unions will honour that agreement and will appreciate the potential of this project to boost the Victorian and Australian economies, and will cooperate in its successful implementation. I should add to that that I felt that members of the Melbourne Olympic Committee who were in discussions with the unions the week before last shared that view and felt that there was unanimous support across the spectrum of industrial relations in Victoria for that view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of a parliamentary delegation from the French National Assembly led my Monsieur Pierre Bourguignon. —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it true that for the first time there will be a woman advocate for the Commonwealth in the national wage case? Can the Minister also explain for the Senate what the Commonwealth position will be in this proposed case?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is true that for the first time the Commonwealth of Australia will be represented by a woman advocate in the national wage case commencing in Melbourne this morning. It is not the first time a woman has appeared in such a case representing one of the major parties; it is the first time for the Commonwealth. The reason why Ms Lynne Tacy of my Department is appearing is that she is simply the best choice to represent the Australian Government's position in the case.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of Senator Giles's question related to the Government's position in the case today. We believe that wage policy in Australia is at a critical stage in that we are transferring from a centralised system to a more decentralised system. It is imperative that in that period of transition there be a continuance of the award restructuring process, of the structural efficiency principle and of the workplace reform that that framework for wage fixation is meant to generate. In all of that we see the role of the Industrial Relations Commission as being central. We will be advocating that the accord-accord mark 6-that this Government enjoys with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) be adopted by the Commission as the basis for wage fixation.

In the Budget we announced tax cuts which effectively reduce the taxation levels for ordinary wage earners in this country and which, on the projections, have improved household disposable income for ordinary Australians.

As part of our submission we will be arguing that the September quarter consumer price index increase should be the basis of the next wage adjustment, followed six months later by a $12 per week increase across the board; that superannuation provision in this country should increase by 3 per cent, phased in over three years commencing in May next year; and that there should be an element of enterprise bargaining in which the emphasis is on sharing between employers and workers the achieved productivity and profitability gains that arise from the restructuring process that has gone on, that being on the basis of no double counting and following the guidelines to be laid down.

That is all on the basis too that the accord commits both the accord partners-the unions and the Government-to an aggregate wage outcome of no more than 7 per cent in the 1990-91 year. We think that the direct bargaining that has characterised the wages landscape over the last few weeks is appropriate, but we do not endorse stoppages of work in support of those particular claims.

In the face of continued restraint and discipline by workers in achieving moderate outcomes for wages, one of the most significant pressures on wage fixation in Australia is that senior executive salaries continue to rise at a rate faster than for the rest of the community. Employers or senior executives are saying to their workers, `Do not do as we do and take massive wage increases, but do as we say and restrain yourselves in a way which we find is comfortable'. The most graphic illustration of this appeared in a recent news- paper article in which a senior executive of a leading Australian company was reported as having a base salary of $1.2m a year. The article said that he had exercised `commendable restraint' in accepting only an 11 per cent increase. In the same newspaper, on the editorial pages, the ACTU's so-called 7 per cent claim-the newspaper was wrong about that-was described as `rapacious'.

A base rate of $1.2m and an 11 per cent increase is seen as commendable restraint at one end of the market. For ordinary Aussie battlers, something less than 7 per cent is regarded as a rapacious claim. The pressure on the wages system is not coming from workers who are observing the accord; it is coming from rapacious executives who, in the face of a need for restraint, ought to exercise it themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask: how does the Australian Government interpret the statement made overnight by Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Khamene'i, that an ongoing presence of non-Islamic believers demands a holy war? Does the Australian Government support the concept of a continuing international force being stationed in the Gulf region to deter aggression by any particular Arab state or to otherwise ensure stability and security in the region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have, of course, noted the wire service reports this morning that the Iranian spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamene'i, has attacked the United States of America military presence in the Gulf-particularly in Saudi Arabia-and has called, as Senator Hill says, for a holy war against what he described as American aggression, greed, plans and policies in the Gulf.

ANSWER.PARA: The statement is, at face value, disturbing and puzzling-puzzling, particularly in the light of previous statements by Iranian leaders that have opposed in very clear terms the Iraqi aggression against Kuwait, called for Iraq's withdrawal and acknowledged the reasons behind the international effort to enforce the blockade against Iraq. It also, of course, runs counter to the quite often stated and re-stated Iranian position of support for international sanctions against Iraq.

As such, it has to be carefully evaluated. I have to say that I am not yet in a position to make a full evaluation of it. We are waiting for further reports as to the context in which the speech was given, and whether there is any evidence of support for it-or that kind of language-in current statements by the civilian leaders, and, of course, we are looking to assessments by other countries with an involvement and interest in the affair.

I would not at this stage want to read too much significance into the statement. It would be inappropriate to react too dramatically. There is a tradition in Iran of really quite extravagant statements emerging from time to time from the clergy, from that side of the polity, which are not always mirrored either in the language or the performance of the Government itself. Clearly, the situation will bear very close watching indeed.

Similarly, I might add that the references yesterday to Iran possibly considering supplying food to Iraq, and giving Iraq an outlet for unspecified products in return, is also a report that needs to be treated with some caution at this stage. There is a continuing discussion going on about the circumstances in which food and medicine might appropriately be allowed into Iraq subject to the humani- tarian exception to the sanctions regime. I do not think it would be proper to assume at this stage that any full-scale breach, or intended breach, by Iran of that sanctions regime is imminent. But, once again, that is an aspect of events that will need very close watching.

As to the last part of Senator Hill's question about the longer term military balance in the region, and the presence or otherwise of foreign or multinational forces, that is very much a question that does remain to be addressed in the event- ual working out and resolution of the whole Gulf affair. I do not think it should be assumed in any way at all that the American Government has any commitment or desire to establish a permanent ongoing presence in the region. It may well be that there is a case for some continuing international presence, whether of a pan-Arab character or of a wider international character.

It may well be that a case can be made, in particular-as I think Secretary of State Baker intimated in his recent congressional testimony-for some presence of American materiel in the Gulf region on an ongoing basis, even if not accompanied by American personnel, but creating, as it were, a capacity to rapidly deploy personnel with equipment there on the ground to cope with contingencies that might arise in the future.

I simply say that all these issues are obviously subject to quite active ongoing discussion and policy formulation within the countries that are involved. It is simply premature to be making any judgments either about the long-term intentions of any of the various players in respect of this, or about what the long-term probabilities are of particular scenarios working themselves out.

Certainly, I do not think there is any rational foundation for the kind of suggestion which seems to underlie the Iranian spiritual leader's speech that the Americans are planning effectively a permanent presence in the region. I do not think there is anything on the record which gives support or foundation for that assumption.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Treasurer indicate how the changes to the provisions announced in the Budget for exempt status for a taxpayer's principal residence will affect those who work in the remote regions of Australia and who rent out their homes while residing elsewhere for a period?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Beahan gave me advance notice of this question and I am able to supply the following answer: under the arrangements applying prior to the Budget announcement, home owners were able to retain capital gains tax exemptions for their principal residence in respect of a period of absence of up to four years, regardless of whether the residence was rented or not during that period. In order to qualify for the temporary residence exemption, it was necessary for the taxpayer to reoccupy the dwelling before sale of the property.

ANSWER.PARA: Recognising that legitimate absences, particularly work related, can result in the taxpayer being absent from his or her principal residence for more than four years, the Government has decided to extend the current four-year period to six years. Whereas an absence in excess of four years previously disqualified the exemption even for the four-year period, the exemption relating to temporary absence will now be lost only in respect of the period of absence in excess of six years. There will be no time constraint on the period of absence qualifying for exemption where the principal residence is not used to produce income.

Finally, recognising the difficulties imposed by the current law for near retirees and others who choose to relocate following a period of absence, owners will no longer be required to move back into their principal residence in order to qualify for the exemption.
The new arrangements are of obvious benefit to those people who are forced to move either to or away from remote areas for work reasons, which really was the substance of Senator Beahan's question.

ANSWER.PARA: What the Opposition has said of course is that it will make the community service obligations a Budget item. Ronnie Boswell knows, and so does every member of the National Party--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order.

—I am going to speak to the point of order too. Mr Deputy President, this is an abuse of Question Time. Twice now the Minister has directed an accusation across the chamber and it is known in the chamber that Senator Boswell has no right to reply to those accusations made petulantly by the Minister for no reason other than the specific purpose of putting in Hansard and putting to the television stations some accusation against Senator Boswell which Senator Boswell has no right to respond to. —I apologise, Mr Deputy President; it is just my friendly Territorian nature. As an advocate, a lobbyist, if you like, of a remote area of Australia, I have been coming down here for 10 years, cap in hand or baseball hat in hand, prostrating myself on the Treasurer's carpet or the carpet of the Minister for Finance and saying--

—Mr Deputy President, I will conclude. Every honourable senator knows how difficult it is, whether a conservative or Labor government is in office in Canberra, to make a case for the bush. ANSWER.PARA: The Government's decision is not only rational but also in the interests of all Australians as opposed to the decision taken by the Opposition on this very important question. So far as the complex details that relate specifically to the honourable senator's question are concerned, the Government has yet to take decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. In relation to the first part of my question, I think the Minister answered that he did not know.
—Yes.

—However, for the benefit of the Australian community, I think we should have some idea when the vagueness of the Beazley option will be filled in particularly with respect to the foreign ownership of Aussat.

—I would have to be stark, staring crazy to stand up in this chamber and answer the honourable senator's question by putting a price on Telecom. It really was a silly question. I have been asked to say how much I think we can get for selling Aussat-how much money we are going to put on it. The Government is not in a position of being able to do that. It will take a decision in due course.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In the light of public concerns about the welfare of the Penan people, will he tell us what responses the Government is getting to the fact that intensive logging of tropical rainforests is continuing in Sarawak in Malaysia? What processes are the Minister and the Government following to address this issue and, in particular, what does the Government intend to do about the importation of tropical timbers from Sarawak?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are concerns around the world about rainforests and logging, not just in the countries which the honourable senator has mentioned. The concerns are not only about the maintenance of the biological diversity but also the maintenance of the culture of indigenous peoples who are threatened by logging. The Hawke Government's conservation policy on rainforests states that `Australia's future timber needs should be met without placing at risk the long term conservation of the rainforest resources of other countries'. Senator Aulich would be aware that last year the Government engaged Coopers and Lybrand and Fortech as consultants to review the extent of Australia's involvement in international trade in tropical timbers, the impacts that trade had on consumers in Australia, and also options for increasing tropical rainforest management and protection. That consultants' report was completed in April of this year and has been reviewed by relevant Government departments.

ANSWER.PARA: The environment movement and many people in this country have been calling for a ban on those tropical timber imports as one part of a package of measures to protect those forests and the biological diversity within them. A group known as Friends of the Penan, with support from other environment and aid groups, has been staging a protest outside the Malaysian High Commission in Canberra in support of tropical forests and the rights of the Penan people. The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is drafting a Cabinet submission on these timber imports and related issues. I think Mrs Kelly will be seeking the joint sponsorship of that submission from Senator Bolkus and Senator Evans in their ministerial capacities.

The kind of issues that have to be considered will include allowing imports of tropical timbers only from those countries which have proper sustainable forestry management plans. I would not deny that such a scheme would be difficult to implement. Nonetheless, that has to be examined. Other issues include encouraging producer countries to set aside some wilderness areas and biosphere reserves for the preservation of biodiversity and, of course, for the security of the culture of those indigenous peoples, like the Penan, whom we have been referring to; improving forestry management practices in producer countries; and ensuring that development assistance activities and overseas aid programs generally are environmentally sound and contribute to ecologically sustainable development of forest resources in the countries to which aid goes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I direct to the Minister for Defence, relates to answers which the Minister gave in the Senate yesterday concerning the upgraded operational role of our warships in the Gulf. This matter was also referred to yesterday in the House of Representatives by the Prime Minister. I ask the Minister: What does he and the Prime Minister mean by `the use of minimum force'? Does it extend to a graduating use of force in the light of circumstances confronting one of our vessels and could it extend to the disabling of a ship?

—One of the three extra operational stages that I said the Australian frigates could go to involves halting. Under the international understanding of halting, that requires a use of force. It requires, obviously, without being too specific, radio contact with the ship concerned and warnings. There is no desire in any of this to see any human life lost. If an Australian frigate were to fire at a ship, it would be required to warn which part of the ship it would fire at so that it should be cleared. The chain of command for such an order at the moment is that the maritime commander and the Chief of the Defence Force are those to whom Cabinet has given responsibility to make that decision, although the CDF has said that he intends, on all available opportunities, to contact me as Minister. If for some reason I am unable to be contacted the decision to fire will be made by the Chief of the Defence Force.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I refer to possible environmental problems which could be caused by constructing a hydrogen peroxide brightening plant at the existing newsprint mill at Albury, New South Wales. I might say that this was raised as a major concern at a recent Murray Valley League conference at Murray Bridge. Does the Government hold the same policy position as some members of the Opposition, who apparently believe that the Albury development should occur first and the environmental and other problems solved later?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that Senator Maguire is referring to remarks by Mr McLachlan, who said that he thought the development should proceed first and there ought to be an examination of environmental consequences later. I do not believe that anyone involved in this debate, with the exception of Mr McLachlan, has that view. Were I a citizen in Adelaide, let alone in any part downriver from where this proposal is meant for, I would have a concern.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously the river system there has been under stress for a long time. The reason that three State governments and the Commonwealth Government have been sitting down over the past few years to try to settle its problems is the massive community concern, not just from consumers in Adelaide but from farmers in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia who have had to witness an ever-decreasing level of production in some areas because of the problems that salination has brought to those areas.

Anything that was done to add to the problems of the Murray-Darling system would be of concern to millions of Australians. The possibility of further pollution of that system should not be opened up without very careful environmental examination. In saying that, while being very critical of Mr McLachlan I am not criticising Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd (ANM), which has offered, as part of its development proposal, to clean up parts of the river. I do not think that ANM is attempting at any point to underestimate the seriousness, the gravity, of the problem that we face.

I think that Opposition members, and Mr McLachlan in particular, ought to think long and hard about how tough they want to appear on environmental issues. The Murray River has had enough. The Murray River can take no more. We ought to think very carefully about any further pollution of that system.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the Budget estimate of $4 billion for unemployment benefit based on an average number of 475,000 beneficiaries over the current financial year. As the current figure is already in excess of 450,000 beneficiaries, with most commentators predicting that the worst is yet to come, does the Government concede that its Budget estimate will almost certainly be exceeded before the end of the financial year and could be brought back on track only if there is a quite dramatic fall in unemployment in the first half of next year? Will the Government please explain whether the Budget estimate is already dead in the water or whether it is expecting a post-Christmas economic recovery of which the rest of the world is as yet blissfully unaware?

—I saw a press release, I think from the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hewson, in the last few weeks. Interestingly enough, Mr Hewson referred to the last big blow-out in unemployment figures which occurred in 1982-83. I hardly need to remind anybody that this Government was not responsible for that hopeless effort, not only in calculating the number of unemployment beneficiaries but as a step in attempting to send this nation broke. Having said that, Mr Hewson and Senator Alston fail to comprehend that the 475,000 is an average figure. I do not think there is any evidence at all that that figure is likely to be exceeded. The Government remains confident that it will be pretty close to the mark. We are well below it now and not likely to approach it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is he aware of the recent press reports of retrenchments in the car industry and annual leave being brought forward? Can he verify these reports and say whether they are the result of restructuring under the car plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been numerous largely inaccurate reports in various newspapers and indeed, on the basis of these reports, people have been ringing my office asking if there is a crisis in the motor vehicle industry at the present time.
—Give them a Kodak solution.

—I will give you a codeine solution, Senator; that is what you need. I have looked at the sales figures and the registration data for the motor vehicle industry up to the most recent months and those figures-which, after all, are the test of what is happening in an industry-are in fact quite different from the picture which might emerge from some of those reports.

ANSWER.PARA: The figures show that motor vehicle sales were still growing strongly and in July were up by about 10 per cent on the figures for the same period last year. I have been told that the preliminary figures for the month of August show the same sort of trend. This is the third year in a row in which sales of locally produced cars have increased. In fact, this year has seen the biggest increase in sales since the start of the motor vehicle plan.

I think it is very important to note that the increased sales have not been coming from imports at the expense of local products. In fact, the share of the imports has decreased this year. It is currently around 23 per cent, compared with some 26 per cent last year. One can only speculate as to why there is all this talk of doom and gloom when the official figures indicate continuing growth in the vehicle market.

I must say that when we began in 1985 with the motor vehicle plan it had three overriding aims. The first was for Australians to be able to buy better quality cars; the second was for cars to be cheaper; and the third was to see a viable and competitive motor vehicle industry in Australia with a real future. Part of those proposals was to create greater competition in the marketplace, and that is what we have got.

If I might deal briefly with each of those issues, there are distinct signs of improved quality in Australian produced cars in the last 18 months or so. For the last eight quarters car price increases have been less than the consumer price index increases and the industry, of course, is enjoying a period of very high and volatile competition. The competition has created problems for some manufacturers because they have to compete. In a competitive market there will be winners and losers and in this current market the consumers are winning. Some sections of the manufacturers are winning and others are not; they tend to be more noisy than those who are.

Much has been achieved but there is still much to be done with the motor vehicle industry. The Industry Commission will report soon and the Government will be making decisions about the arrangements which will succeed the car plan when it runs out in 1992. It is not appropriate for me to speculate on the outcome of the Industry Commission report, but the existing plan has given the industry a stable policy framework, which we will ensure exists after 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. I refer the Minister to the announcement in the Budget in 1989 that the Moomba-Sydney gas pipeline was to be sold, as part of the Government's program of asset sales, and to the reaffirmation contained in the 1990 Budget of the intention to sell the pipeline. In respect of the proposed sale, I ask the Minister, first, whether under the formal legal agreements between the Pipeline Authority and the Australian Gas Light Company, AGL has the right of first refusal in any sale of the pipeline. Secondly, is the method which has been announced by the Government for the sale of the asset contrary to the 1974 haulage agreement or the 1985 heads of agreement between the Pipeline Authority and AGL and, if so, in what ways?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of the question relates to the original haulage agreement entered into in 1974 between the Pipeline Authority and the Australian Gas Light Company. Senator Short asked whether the AGL would be given the right of first refusal in any sale of the pipeline. The answer to that part of the question, I am advised, is no.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, Senator Short asked whether the method which has been announced by the Government for the sale of the asset is contrary in any way to the 1974 haulage agreement or the 1985 heads of agreement between the Pipeline Authority and AGL. The answer to that question is contained in the request for a proposal to purchase, a document published by the Department of Finance which in paragraph 32, I think it is, makes the point that it is the Government which is involved in the sale and not the Authority. I read from that document:

It is not proposed to give such a power to the TPA. Respondents should note that it is the Government through the agency of the task force on asset sales and not the TPA which will be arranging the sale of the Moomba-Sydney pipeline system on behalf of the Commonwealth. It is proposed that the transfer of ownership of the pipeline system and TPA's obligation to AGL and the gas producers will be effected by legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that answer and ask him a supplementary question in relation to his response that the AGL does not have right of first refusal. Is that response based on advice sought or received by the Minister for Finance from the Attorney-General or the Attorney-General's Department? Has the Attorney-General, or the Attorney-General's Department, expressed concern to the Minister for Finance or the Prime Minister about the legality of the course of action proposed for the sale of the pipeline? If so, what was the nature of that concern expressed by the Attorney-General or the Attorney-General's Department?

—I cannot answer that part of the question at present. My advice in answering the question, I assume, came from the Department of Finance. I shall try to obtain an answer to the specific parts of the supplementary question. I know that the Attorney-General had some involvement in the discussions relating to this matter, but I do not know the nature of the advice given by the Attorney-General to the Department of Finance, and I shall endeavour to clarify that for the honourable senator.
—I refer the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs to the recent announcement of a proposal to introduce a drug free policy in the Australian Federal Police. What stage has that proposal reached?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Mr Peter McAulay, has floated the idea of a drug free policy that should operate within the Australian Federal Police. He has done so because of concerns about health and safety aspects but also, of course, concerns about the security and integrity of the Australian Federal Police in its operations and in the way in which the community is entitled to hold it in very high regard. If it is given the task, as it has been, to enforce our drug laws nationwide, the Australian people are entitled to be confident that the members of the Australian Federal Police are themselves not indulging in the use of those illegal drugs.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commissioner is satisfied, I may say, about those provisions in the regulations governing the Federal Police dealing with alcohol, which of course is a drug which can cause problems of a health and safety nature. But as far as the question of illegal drugs is concerned, this is a matter which he is giving particular emphasis to. I believe he will be able to call on the experience of international organisations which have adopted such a drug free policy for their work forces and on the experience of some organisations with Australia. I believe that elements of the various testing procedures adopted to combat the use of drugs in sport here in Australia may also be of use in devising a regime to implement this policy.

I believe that the cooperation of the Australian Federal Police Association in any such move is absolutely crucial to its success, both as to the testing of entrants and then as to members of the Federal Police during the time of their contracts with the Federal Police. I understand that such discussions with the union are taking place at the moment.

I believe that this matter of a drug free policy for law enforcement agencies is a matter of much wider concern than simply that of the Australian Federal Police, and I am seeking to put the matter on the agenda of the Australian Police Ministers Council, which is meeting later this year, to see whether a nationwide approach might not be adopted in relation to a drug free policy in Australian law enforcement agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Given the existing community service obligations of the Commonwealth Bank, which include exemption from account fees for pensioners, other long term beneficiaries and people under 18, special banking packages for charities, free bank statements in braille for visually impaired customers, subsidised electronic banking for disabled customers, and a social as well as a commercial emphasis on lending decisions by the Commonwealth Development Bank, will the Minister give an assurance that the Commonwealth Bank will continue to meet these and other community service obligations, whether or not the Treasurer succeeds in his ill-conceived attempt to partially privatise the people's bank? Secondly, will the Minister safeguard the performance of these obligations by appropriately detailed legislative amendments? Finally, will the Minister support the establishment of a Senate select committee to assess the performance of the Bank's community service obligations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is nice to see the Commonwealth Bank being cast in such a warm glow by Senator Spindler. I do not agree with the honourable senator's assessment of the various matters which he read out as being `community service obligations'. Telecom Australia, for example, has community service obligations which are imposed on it by government. The Commonwealth Bank, as I understand it, does not have community service obligations imposed on it by government. What it depends on very much is the Bank's policy in relation to the sorts of services which Senator Spindler refers to, some of which may even have been loss-making in themselves but which are, nevertheless, designed to attract and maintain the patronage of particular community groups for essentially commercial reasons.

ANSWER.PARA: I might say that other banks, private banks, do some of the same sort of thing in various areas of their activities, which suggests that the Commonwealth Bank's community service efforts, as the honourable senator puts them, may be more palatable and attractive to him than some of the services or special benefits provided by other banks. It is a matter of taste.

Having made that point, I doubt very much that the management of the Commonwealth Bank would want to change the policies which have made it so attractive to many of those community groups. After all, it is in the banking business and it has clients and customers whose allegiance it wishes to retain.

I should add that the Commonwealth Government will remain effectively the dominant shareholder in the bank, so legislation to guarantee policy objectives will not necessarily prove essential. Finally, Senator Spindler asked me about whether there should be a Senate committee investigation of this matter. Senate committees are often useful bodies but I doubt that this would be so in the case of the Commonwealth Bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's suggestion that the whole banking sector should be, or is, currently involved in meeting community service obligations, would he be supportive of the suggestion that such legislation should be extended to the whole banking sector?

—First of all, I do not know what legislation the honourable senator is talking about. It just happens that the Commonwealth Government is the majority shareholder in the Commonwealth Bank, or will be the majority shareholder, and there is legislation-I think it is called the Commonwealth Banking Act. I did not say anything about private sector banks fulfilling community service obligations to people. What I said first of all was that I did not believe that the sort of services which you referred to in your question were in fact community service obligations. They were, if you like, marketing bait for the customers of the Commonwealth Bank which keeps them happy-me amongst them. Banks adopt different strategies to look after the interests of their customers, and they should be entitled to do so. What the honourable senator wants seemingly to put on the whole banking sector is the palsied hand of Democrat warm inner glow.

—My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia who is, as well, a member of the Wet Tropics Ministerial Council responsible for the management of Queensland's World Heritage listed northern rainforests. I refer the Minister to his answer on 28 May, some three months ago, to a question asked by Senator Reynolds on the steps being taken by the Government to protect the interests of the timber workers at the Ravenshoe Mill. The Minister then said that the company was in a position to retain its existing work force, trade its way out of its problems, and was on the market to be sold as a going concern. Will the Minister update the Senate on the current position of the Ravenshoe Mill, its workers and its creditors, and reconcile this with the Government's pledge that `no-one will be disadvantaged by the World Heritage listing'?

—Yes, I will. I know that the Federal Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, who is directly responsible for this particular issue, has recently been again to Ravenshoe. I know that officers from her own staff have spoken to the workers at the mill again, and that there is great concern about what is going on there. There have been a number of recent developments, which I am personally not across because I was not the Minister that actually went to visit the mill; the Minister responsible did. I will speak to the Minister, Mrs Kelly, today, and I will provide a full answer for Senator Boswell in the Senate tomorrow.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I inform the Minister that the mill has gone into receivership. The Government has given $8m, which has disappeared. Has the Government made a full investigation into where the millions of dollars of taxpayers' money given to the mill has gone and the reason for the financial failure of the mill? If so, will the results be made publicly available?

—I have just confirmed that we are extremely concerned about what has happened at Ravenshoe. One of the major concerns that the Minister expressed to me personally when I was with her in attending the Wet Tropics Ministerial Council meeting was about what has happened to the very significant assistance that this Government, in good faith, gave to the mill to resurrect its fortunes. Those matters are being investigated, and I can assure Senator Boswell that I will give him a full answer in the Senate tomorrow after I speak to the Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it true that the Government met yesterday with the public sector unions on their current wage claims? What is the Government's position in these wage negotiations? Does this jeopardise the current wage fixation system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, in the guise of the Department of Industrial Relations acting on behalf of the other departments, agencies and government business enterprises, met all the public sector unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions yesterday on the wages claim that those unions have lodged on the Government as part of this current wages round. I must say that it was a very a constructive discussion.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's position is to indicate to public sector employees that we will honour our undertakings in accord mark 6, that we will support a wage increase equivalent to the September quarter consumer price index and that six months after the operative date of that wage increase we will support a $12 across-the-board wage increase as well as an adjustment to superannuation of 3 per cent to be phased in over three years from 1 May.

In terms of the recognition of government awards as paid rates awards-that is, awards in which there is no over-award component-and whether or not classifications similar to those employed by the Government in the private sector, because of over-award negotiations or site agreements, have moved ahead of paid rates awards, we will accept some degree of market comparability in Commonwealth public sector wage fixation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has happened to the last productivity gains we were supposed to have?

—I am talking about market comparability. The honourable senator is on another cloud entirely. If it is not cloud nine, I do not know what it is. In respect of market rates, we have advised the unions that we would want to conduct an examination to see prima facie whether Commonwealth rates are out of kilter in any way with rates operating in the private sector and whether the conduct of market surveys is appropriate.

ANSWER.PARA: I might say that the Government has indicated that that is its position as far as its employees are concerned. But the operative date of the first increase and the endorsement of the package is subject to the national wage case proceedings before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Our offer stands on the basis that the Commission, which is central to wage fixation, determines an operative date and an endorsement of the package.

That, I think, in part answers the second part of the question-that is, does it threaten the system?. The short answer is no, it does not, because of the central processes of the Industrial Relations Commission.

I might also add that we believe that entering into direct negotiations with our employees, as represented by their unions, is an appropriate course of action. I am somewhat surprised that some other employers do not seem to share that view. We think the way in which the Government has approached these negotiations is an example for constructively facing our responsibilities to our employees and to recognise their real wage needs within the terms of the accord and within the commitment in the accord that the Australian Council of Trade Unions has pledged itself to adhere to-that the aggregate wage outcome for Budget year 1990-91 has a ceiling of 7 per cent. While that figure of 7 per cent has been bandied around as if it is a maximum wage outcome for this year, we have to recognise that in the pipeline that makes up the 7 per cent there is a 3 to 3 1/2 per cent pipeline from last year and there is an allocation of wages drift in the wages system of about one to 1 1/2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and follows the answer that he gave earlier to Senator Hill with regard to Iran. What is the Australian Government's assessment of the basis for Iran and Iraq resuming diplomatic relations? What are the announced terms and what are the unannounced terms? Despite the Minister's `don't know' attitude in his answer to Senator Hill earlier in Question Time, I ask: Surely Iran's decision to send food to Iraq in return for money and oil is a breaking of the United Nations (UN) trade embargo? What representations to Iran are Australia and our allies-and, indeed, the UN itself-making to resist this breaking of the sanctions? Finally, I ask: Does not the Minister support in principle the extension of UN sanctions to Iran in at least the circumstances where Iranian ships carry Iraqi oil and in the circumstances where Iran contracts now to receive Iraqi oil in the future in return for now busting sanctions to Iraq's advantage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague's indignation, I am afraid, is not quite justified by the quality of his information. I have made it clear that the only information we have in respect of possible sanctions breaches by Iran is a reported newspaper comment to the effect that Iran is considering supplying food to Iraq and might give Iraq an outlet for unspecified products in return.

ANSWER.PARA: I have indicated, not through any indifference or casual response but simply because of a lack of information at this stage, that we ought not to get too excited about these reports. They do not appear to reflect explicit Iranian Government statements. They are at odds with previous very clear statements about Iran's position on the Gulf crisis and the question of the appropriateness of the sanctions.

There is also a question that has to be addressed by the international community, in any event, about some possible scope for humanitarian exceptions to the sanctions regime in the food and medicine area, although the context of the report does not suggest that it was being put in that way. So it is simply appropriate caution rather than any other characteristic that leads me to respond as I do on that particular question.

As to the whole question of the Iran-Iraq rapprochement and diplomatic settlement, that is in itself something that the international community ought to wholly welcome. It was a bloody, unproductive and appalling war that was fought between the two countries over eight years with the loss of some one million lives. If the two countries, for whatever reason, whatever motives, have found it possible to reach agreement or a settlement, and do so on appropriate terms, they will be acting in accordance with the resolutions of the United Nations, which has urged the parties to do just that.

We, of course, hope that none of this will reflect itself in any undermining of the international sanctions effort against Iraq. We will, of course, be making strenuous representations to Iran and acting in consort with the rest of the international community as appropriate should it appear that the Iranians are, in fact, embarked upon such a course. But, I repeat, it is premature to make any such judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short asked me a question a few days ago relating to the State Bank of Victoria. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 August Senator Brownhill asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the decision to abolish the 1c and 2c coins. I found it too difficult, as Senator Brownhill will recall, and the Treasurer has provided me with the following information in answer to that question: First of all, the application by Australia Post to increase the cost of the standard article postage rate from 41c to 43c from 3 September 1990 was approved by the Prices Surveillance Authority and is in no way related to the decision to cease issuing the 1c and 2c coins. The Government's decision on 1c and 2c coins does not mean that the cost of postage stamps will rise to 45c. It has long been a common practice for many people to buy more than one stamp at a time.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the problem I got into when I was trying to explain to the honourable senator that I was not good at mathematics or particularly philosophy. The point is simple: if one is buying a 41c stamp, and one does not have any 1c coins any more, one will probably pay 45c for it, but if a number of stamps is bought, the picture is different. Australia Post--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the pensioners?
—You've got to buy 43 stamps.
—Order! It is a bit too early in the morning for arithmetic.
—What about the Aussie battlers?
—If Senator Patterson were to settle down a bit I would answer the question. I do not know what on earth has brought on this outburst of enthusiasm.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia Post will be actively promoting the sale of its standard stamps in multiples of five. Senator Short and Senator Brownhill should work it out; they got it wrong. This is consistent with the merchandising trend for many small value items and will remove the need to consider the question of rounding. Concerns that the cessation of issues of 1c and 2c coins will be inflationary are unwarranted. A number of Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, including Denmark, Norway, Sweden, France and, most recently, New Zealand have ceased to issue or have withdrawn their lowest denomination coins and have not experienced inflationary problems as a result.

There is no reason to expect that the position in Australia will be different. The cent will remain the basic unit of account in price setting. Goods sold by supermarkets and other retail outlets can still be priced in lc stops. Rounding is intended to apply to the payment of bills rather than the pricing of goods. Many retail goods are of course normally purchased in multiples rather than individually. So, only the final bill for payment will need to be rounded. The question of rounding arises only where final bills are paid in cash. Payments by cheque, credit card or electronic funds transfer at point of sale will not be affected and should continue to be made to the exact cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-When I moved the motion for a message to be sent to the House of Representatives asking the House to resume consideration of the End of War List Bill, I was well aware that the Standing Orders of both Houses provide that consideration of Bills introduced in either House in a previous session may be resumed at the instigation or request of the initiating House, except where a general election has intervened. SPEECH.PARA: That principle would have been preserved if the House of Representatives had suspended its standing order, as the Senate did when it passed my motion, and passed the Bill. The Senate as presently constituted would have agreed that the Bill pass, and the House as presently constituted would have agreed that the Bill pass. SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.

The speech read as follows-

The modernisation of Australia's extradition laws has been an integral part of this government's strategy in the war against crime. It is no secret that crime is increasingly taking on an international perspective. There is no starker example of the international dimensions of crime than the drug trade. Not only is there an importation of illicit drugs but also there is the associated exportation of money from Australia to pay for this filthy merchandise. Often legitimate international business channels are used to make just such payments.

This government has taken significant initiatives to combat crime within Australia. The Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 provides for a comprehensive regime of freezing and confiscation designed to attack the very motive for crime, profit. The cash transaction reports act 1988 establishes regimes for the reporting of significant cash transactions, the reporting of suspect transactions and for the verification of identity of persons opening accounts. These measures will greatly assist law enforcement by producing criminal intelligence and creating a money trail for large amounts of cash. Having established these measures domestically the next step is to reach agreements with other nations that will facilitate international cooperation in the fight against crime. The mutual assistance in criminal matters act 1987 provides just such a mechanism. Where Australia has a mutual assistance relationship with a foreign nation many of these domestic remedies may be available to that other nation. Similarly, domestic remedies regarding the freezing and confiscation of assets in that country may be able to be used by Australian law enforcement agencies. This government has actively pursued the negotiation of mutual assistance treaties with other nations and to date has concluded 9 treaties, with 16 in various stages of negotiations.

Complementary to these measures is the modernisation of Australia's extradition relationships. The government formed a task force to negotiate modern bilateral extradition treaties or extradition arrangements. So far treaties or arrangements have been negotiated with 26 countries, with 14 in various stages of negotiations. In 1988 the Parliament passed a modern extradition Act. In light of the experience with the act over the past 12 months or so a need for some technical `fine tuning' of the legislation has become apparent. The Bill before the Senate contains those technical amendments.

I propose to deal only briefly with the more significant of these amendments. As section 11 of the Act now stands it is not possible to list in regulations all countries to which Australia can extradite for crimes created pursuant to multilateral treaties such as the hijacking convention and the convention for the protection of internationally protected persons. It is clearly desirable that all Australians be able to ascertain easily the crimes for which extradition can be considered and all the countries to which Australia can extradite for those crimes. The amendments to section 11 are designed to enable the regulations to comprehensively list the countries to which persons may be extradited for `multilateral offences'. Other amendments streamline Australia's extradition relationship with New Zealand where a person consents to being surrendered to New Zealand. Finally, a new provision is inserted into the Extradition Act 1988 which will give police power to arrest, without warrant, a person who is about to abscond. A detailed explanation of all the amendments is set out in the explanatory memorandum.
Financial impact
The amendments included in the Bill will involve no additional expenditure.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to discuss a number of matters that arose during the recess between when this chamber met in June and when it met again in August. I would like to talk about some of the issues that were raised with me when I travelled around Queensland during that time. In particular, I want to mention the number of young people to whom I spoke in schools throughout Queensland, starting with my old school-the Southport School on the Gold Coast-and ranging through a number of schools in places such as Cairns, Charters Towers, Rockhampton, smaller schools in places such as Homestead and Prairie and other schools in Hughenden, Richmond, Julia Creek, Cloncurry, Mount Isa and Kenilworth.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things school children continually said to me as I travelled around was that they were gravely concerned that the present parliamentarians did not seem to answer the concerns of many people of their generation and, of course, my generation. I think it is very sad that we have a large number of young Australians-Australians who will be the future leaders of this country-who do not believe that the parliamentary process answers the needs of the people.

The reason we are sent to this place is to represent our States and the people who make up those States. One of the things I say to young people as I travel around is that it is up to them to make the most use of the processes that exist, which means that there must be more interaction and that the interaction must run in both ways. It must not just be parliamentarians going to the electorate and pushing their views to the people; it must also be a process by which the people can have access to their parliamentarians and the parliamentarians represent them here in Canberra and here in the Senate.

I think it is very important that we as senators listen to what is said. It is very easy in this chamber for us to feel that we are somehow special, that we are somehow sequestered from the rest of Australia and that because we do not have a constituency per se, as exists with the House of Representatives, we can ignore the wishes of the people. One thing that is very obvious from my travels around Queensland is that this is not the role that the people see us as having to play. They see us as a very important link in the processes in Canberra and they see us as extra local members.

I was very pleased to have the opportunity to visit schools and to talk to school students about what we do here in Canberra, because there is a great lack of understanding among our school students of what happens and many of them feel very alienated by the processes, by the media, by the whole aura of parliament.

It is very fitting and proper that parliament is conducted in a manner that displays decorum. It is very fitting and proper that the deliberations of the Senate are solemn deliberations, because we are concerned with the national interest. It is not proper, however, that we should use this opportunity to divorce ourselves from the people. We should remain approachable and accountable and should always have very firmly in our sights an obligation to be so. That involves, therefore, an obligation to be willing to talk to people about the decisions we make.

One of the great difficulties in this age of modern media is that the media necessarily simplifies many of the things we say. We in the chamber all know how complex many issues are; how many hours or days or weeks of deliberation and careful thought we give to these matters before we come into the chamber. Sometimes it can be very disappointing that all of that careful thought and careful consideration is condensed into one or two lines of newsprint at the very best. Therefore, I think it is very important that we go out to the electorate and give people the opportunity to ask us questions and to seek from us information and elucidation over the decisions that we make here in Canberra.

The other thing that is important in travelling around the electorate is talking to people and finding out what is of concern to them. It is very easy while we sit in Canberra, in our comfortable chairs behind our big desks, for us to get too wrapped up in the processes of Canberra, to become Canberra-ised. Of course, as far as the electorate is concerned, many of the matters that may seem personally or politically important to us are unimportant. The people have a different view of what is happening in Australia and of what is of concern to them.

I take this opportunity to raise a number of the issues that were brought to me by ordinary people in Queensland and which I said I would raise here in our national capital. Obviously, one of the most important issues for the people of Queensland-an issue that was raised first in Toowoomba but also in Longreach, Winton, Muttaburra, Richmond, Rockhampton and Ingham-is the Federal Government proposal to license road transport within this country.

One of the points that was made to me by people throughout Queensland-not just in small towns like Muttaburra but in big towns along the coast, separated from Brisbane-is that the Federal Government proposals on road transport and its proposed licence fees for the road transport industry will have disastrous consequences. These proposals will affect not just the many small people in the industry, the battlers who work very hard to take the produce from where it is grown to the markets, the people who work during the nights when we are asleep to take the goods from the capital cities and deliver them to the provincial centres; they will also have a terrible impact on everybody outside the capital cities, not just in Queensland but in many other States, who relies on road transport.

It is wholly inequitable, unjust and unfair that small operators, who may have put 10 or 15 years service into the road transport industry, should be pushed out of that industry in the face of Government proposals that will see the licence fees, for example, for a road train operator increase from $5,000 a year to $42,000 a year-fees which the Federal Government expects to be paid up front. It is unacceptable that these many small, hardworking Australian businessmen- because truck drivers are businessmen-should be forced out of their business and their livelihoods. It is unacceptable that their families should have their prosperity, security and happiness jeopardised because of a bureaucratic system that wishes to push these people off the roads for some perceived benefit in putting freight on to rail. I state clearly that we must all recognise that although rail reform is important, one will never make the railway more efficient by making the road network less efficient.

A point that was continually raised as I travelled around Queensland is that the Federal Government has the means here and now to do something about the road network if it wants to do so. Every year the Federal Government receives from ordinary Australians-from ordinary motorists, truck drivers and so on-over $6 billion in Federal fuel excise. Yet as I travelled around Queensland the question asked of me over and over again was, `How much money does the Federal Government give us back?'. The answer is a little over $1 billion-$1 billion of the $6 billion that is paid at the bowser is spent on the roads. That is a sad indictment of this Federal Government and of its priorities when we talk about provincial Australia.

It is clear that many roads throughout Queensland and provincial Australia are wholly unsatisfactory. Although people in the capital cities may feel some degree of personal dissatisfaction if the pothole outside their driveway is not repaired in one week or two, many people throughout provincial Queensland do not even have a bitumen road in which to develop a pothole. Many of them, at best, have four metres of bitumen which passes as a national highway, and many have to drive hundreds of kilometres every week, to go to town or to schools or to the shops, on dirt roads that are totally unusable in the wet. The consequence is that many people cannot even get from their home to town when it rains. Many of these people are the real underprivileged of this country-the people for whom this Federal Government does not seem to give much consideration. Despite all the talk by the Federal Government about caring for provincial Australia, it is very clear that when it comes down to the real issues in provincial Australia-real issues such as whether the road is there or not or whether one can use it when it rains-the Federal Government has turned its back. Now it comes along with a scheme to raise more and more money in those areas which seem to receive less and less each year.

One of the statistics handed to my office in the recent recess was that the local government funding in Queensland would increase in money terms by 3.2 per cent this year. Inflation runs at between 6 per cent and 7 per cent in Queensland. The consequence is that many local authorities that rely on Federal Government funding to attempt to maintain their hundreds, or in some cases thousands, of kilometres of road will have a reduced ability to do so. The consequence of this real cut in local government funding in many of the very disadvantaged and underprivileged areas of Australia will be more social dislocation, fewer services or a lower standard of services. This again is a sad indictment of the policies of this Government.

As I travelled around I also spoke to many wool growers and many horticulturalists and small farmers. As we all know, they too are reeling from the consequences of the last couple of years of this Labor Government. Let me talk, for example, about the problems faced by the navy bean industry and the peanut industry in Kingaroy, Queensland, because these people are on the point of bankruptcy. It is these small farmers who are facing the very real prospect of being forced off their land. It is these small farmers who will bear the brunt of the 51 per cent decline in farm incomes that was highlighted by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics in its report but a couple of weeks ago. One of the reasons why they face a declining market and why they face the very real prospect of less money every week to pay the bills to send their kids to school or to pay for the clothes or the shoes that the children need is that the market in Australia is being flooded with cheap imports that are being dumped from overseas, and yet we see no willingness on the part of the Government to face up to the issue of dumping.

The last two times, from my understanding, that the Federal Government has used anti-dumping legislation were: firstly, the protection of the vinyl floor covering industry in respect of floor coverings less than one millimetre in depth; and secondly, the protection of the piezoelectronic thermometer industry. Well, I do not pretend to know anything about piezoelectronic thermometers, apart from the fact that they do not grow on trees, and I do not know many people who produce them. But I do know many people who produce peanuts and navy beans and who face the prospect of cheap inferior products being dumped from places such as China, Israel and the United States- a prospect which is going to destroy the livelihood of the producers and their families.

The question I ask-this should be of great importance to us all-is what are we going to do for these real Australian battlers? What importance do we place on the survival of rural industries in this country? Are we as a Senate and are we as representatives of the people going to turn our backs on these hard-working battling Australians or are we going to stand up for them and represent them in this place and in the deliberations of this Parliament?

I believe that if we are going to turn our backs on these small farmers, like this Federal Government has done, then we are failing in our duty as representatives of the people, and we are failing to keep firmly in view the idea that we should have one Australia where people could work together for the greater prosperity of all. If we turn our backs on primary producers, if we turn our backs on provincial Australia, then what really is left of this economy, and what really is left of the Australian vision of a better place for us all? I think the answer to that is a very disappointing view of Australia and a very disappointing future for many young Australians in my generation. I think these are the issues that are very important in Queensland and throughout this country.

I would hope that over the next couple of weeks this Senate will have a greater opportunity to discuss these issues and a number of other issues that I intend to raise in the next few weeks. I would hope that the Government might see fit to pay attention to what the representatives of the people of this country, the representatives of the people of Queensland, have to say on these matters, and I will be looking forward to the response of the Government in seeing some action from them. But at the moment I see very little action at all. Therefore, it gives me a great deal of concern for the future of Queensland, for the future of Australia, and for the future of my generation of young Australians.

I will advise the Commonwealth Development Bank to wait to put the company into receivership until the negotiations are finalised one way or the other.
