SPEECH.PARA: Another of the 80 cases which I have tabled in the Senate is referred to by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia as `the Rigg incident'. That is its term for an incident which I have cited on a number of occasions previously. It has been the subject of correspondence between the managing director of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and myself. That correspondence has previously been tabled by former Senator Stone and is available for the perusal of honourable senators.

I now propose to expose, to the Australian people, 'the Rigg incident' in detail. I am sad to say that honourable senators have not shown a great deal of interest in it, but many people in the community are very interested in the details. I will do so over a period of two adjournment speeches. I draw Senator Alston's attention to the fact that I will be tabling many documents because the allegations that I am making are very serious and must be supported by the documentary evidence, much of which has been previously tabled by leave.

In 1982 the bank saw the need to improve its return on foreign currency assets by providing foreign currency lending to Australian customers. I am going back to 1982 and I will describe, step by step, a profit making strategy which was pursued by all Australian banks. It finally led to-in what is known as `the foreign loans fiasco'-the demise of approximately 1,400 Australian businesses.
In a bank memorandum from the general manager dated 16 March 1982 entitled `Foreign Currency Lending to Australian Customers', it is stated:
The subject is considered important for the following reasons:

(c) The need to improve our return on foreign currency assets generally. In the study conducted last year . . . comment was made on the rate of return being achieved on our overseas assets-a return somewhat less than our domestic assets . . . there was an evident need to have a greater content of the higher yielding commercial loans on our books . . . our lending should be directed to areas that will give a higher return than is achievable from prime corporate business.

What this memorandum is saying is that customers at the bank-I am talking of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia-other than prime corporate business should be targeted by offering foreign currency loans at the highest return achievable by the bank. The new philosophy of banking was beginning to emerge even preceding deregulation-the philosophy of maximising profit even at the expense of customers. We see the beginning of the erosion of the ethos of banking in this country which has progressively got to the stage where we have nothing worse than an outrageous set of circumstances in banking in Australia. Who the customers were, and what the margins were, is explained in the memorandum:

This lending should be directed to the small and medium size business area for development, investment and other financing requirements . . . I would see this lending attracting fees and margins a good deal higher than those for existing Australian borrowers . . . fees and margins could be pitched at levels to match or better those applying for domestic bill facilities.

So here we have the ethos of banking being spelt out in an internal memorandum. It is clearly targeting small business in this country and is beginning to create a foreign borrowing facility to maximise the bank's profits to the detriment of its customers. Domestic bill facilities traditionally carried high interest rates and high fees and margins.

What the memorandum is saying is that the bank will offer an expensive facility to customers who do not have the bargaining power to negotiate a better deal. That is naked greed. We have seen a good deal of it from the banking sector in the deregulated banking context since 1984-85.

Mr Rigg, to whom I have referred on a number of occasions in this place, never needed a foreign currency loan; all he needed was the first mortgage finance to build commercial lease premises and a factory at South Nowra. As we shall see, the bank's greed was such that Mr Rigg would be offered a facility calculated to extract every last drop of blood out of his business.
There was a problem in 1982-the cost of hedging against the exchange risk. The memorandum continues:

The more contentious risk is, of course, the exchange risk . . . it is now possible to use the hedge market to cover the risk which would mean that all up costs should broadly match the costs of AUD finance.

In other words, the cost to the customer of entering a hedged foreign currency loan was about the same as entering into a domestic loan. Accordingly the bank had a product it could not sell. The bank's greed was to overcome this. I will be seeking leave to table a memorandum.

How was the bank to induce customers to accept fees and margins for foreign currency loans which were pitched at levels to match those applying for domestic bill facilities? It is simple. The foreign currency loans were to be offered to the targeted customers in conjunction with a domestic bill facility. That ploy was explained in a bank memorandum by Messrs B. Moran and J. L. Edwards, dated 15 April 1982, entitled `Foreign Currency Loans to Australian Borrowers':
When considering applications for existing or prospective customers . . . it is recommended that the following course of action be introduced immediately:
* All applications of $250,000 or more for bill facilities to assist with capital expenditure (working or otherwise) are to be approved . . . as a `bills discount/offshore finance facility'.
* The CTB will have the option to exercise either facility at each rollover . . .

That is worth marking well. The bank was to decide, upon its own motion, whether to adopt the foreign currency loan on any roll-over of the domestic bill facility. I will be seeking leave to table a memorandum from which I have just quoted.

How is the bank to overcome the problem of hedging costs? This, also, was simple-make the customer wear the exchange risk. That ploy was explained as follows in a bank memorandum by Messrs J. O'Brien, dated 6 May 1982, entitled, `Foreign Currency Facilities for Australian Customers':

. . . it is highly unlikely clients would readily accept foreign currency loans . . . unless they and the CTB are prepared to allow the facility to proceed on an unhedged basis. The statement is regularly made that the cost of hedged foreign currency loans is approximately equal to the cost of borrowing funds in Australia . . .

I will be seeking leave to table that memorandum. The bank left no doubt that it would not, itself, accept the exchange risk. Added to a bank memorandum of Mr J. B. Gledhill, dated 6 May 1982, entitled, `Senior Managers Comments', is a handwritten note as follows:
I assume it is intended that in no circumstances will the CTB itself accept any exchange risk in respect of overseas borrowings.

The response was yes, also written in the margin of the memorandum. I will be seeking leave to table that memorandum. Accordingly, if Mr Rigg had applied to the bank for finance in June 1982 he would have been provided with: (a) a bills discount facility with offshore finance options; (b) the option, to be exercised at the bank's discretion, upon any roll-over of a bank facility; (c) fees and margins to be the same as for the bill facility and the offshore finance; (d) Rigg to accept the exchange risk; (e) Rigg to pay withholding tax on interest payments to offshore lenders.

The mechanics applicable to the facility would have been, first of all, that Mr Rigg would sign a bill, leaving the identity of the acceptor of the bill blank. Secondly, the bank would negotiate the bill to an independent dealer on an open money market; the dealer's name would be inserted on the bill as acceptor; the dealer would purchase the bill at a discount, representing interest payable to the dealer; and the bank would credit the discount amount to Mr Rigg's account. I am describing precisely the procedure that was used in approximately 1,400 such negotiated offshore loans.

Thirdly, upon the maturity of the bill the bank would pay the full face value of the bill to the dealer and debit that amount to Mr Rigg's account. For providing that service, the bank would charge its usual fees and margins. The bank would not act as lender to Mr Rigg and would be in no way exposed. Fourthly, the bill could then be rolled over, or a foreign currency loan substituted. In the latter case, the bank would negotiate with an offshore financier to lend to Mr Rigg direct the foreign currency equivalent necessary to pay out the discounted bill facility. Fifthly, Mr Rigg would pay periodic instalments of interest in the foreign currency to the offshore financier, less withholding tax. Sixthly, any downward movement of the Australian dollar against the foreign currency would be a loss to Mr Rigg, payable to the offshore financier.

Seventhly, any upward movement of the Australian dollar against the foreign currency would be a profit to Mr Rigg, payable by the offshore financier. By providing that service, the bank would charge its usual fee and margins and would not act as lender to Mr Rigg.
Finally, upon maturity of the foreign loan, Mr Rigg might pay out the loan by way of a fresh bill facility from the bank, for the Australian dollar equivalent necessary to discharge the loan.

The bills discount facility with offshore finance options would have been in accordance with the normal market practice. However, that facility would deny the bank the substantial profits it could earn by going behind market practice and inducing customers to enter into sham transactions.

In the case of the bills discount facility, all the bank had to do was discount the bill to itself, inserting its own name as acceptor of the bill. The bill would be kept at the customer's branch of the bank and not negotiated on the open money market. The bank's money market dealers would fix the interest rate and the bank would lend the money on the bill to the customer. In this way, the bank would receive the interest that would otherwise be payable to the independent dealer and would receive its usual fees and margins as well.

The offshore finance options would have been abandoned altogether. The bank would want to lend to the customer itself but would not accept the exchange risk of borrowing the foreign currency to on-sell to its customer. Accordingly, the bank would have to acquire the foreign currency by way of a currency swap, thereby incurring no exchange risk itself. The bank would then lend to the customer in Australian dollars but induce the customer to enter a forward exchange contract in the foreign currency acquired pursuant to the swap. Accordingly, the bank would `simulate' a foreign currency loan and `simulate' the exchange rate.

In this way the bank would receive the interest that would otherwise be payable to the offshore financier, would receive its usual fees and margins and would gain a potentially enormous profit from the downward movement of the Australian dollar against foreign currency. In reality, of course, there was no exchange risk for the customer, only a contractual pretence calculated to enhance the profits of the bank at the expense of the customer. Both of these sham transactions, if adopted by the bank, would, of course, be fraudulent.

The concept of currency swaps and simulated foreign currency loans were known to the bank in mid-1984. A bank memorandum from International Division, Accounting Department, dated 13 June 1984, entitled ,`Australian Interest Withholding Tax' provided as follows:
. . . avenues being used in the market to obtain withholding tax free funds include-

* Simulated or synthetic foreign currency loans, i.e. an AUD loan is obtained from an Australian resident (eg the CTB) and a hedge contract simultaneously taken out to `create' a USD liability. The USD equivalent of the AUD loan and interest are effectively sold forward. Obviously, this technique could also be used to create liabilities in other currencies as well.
* Currency swap arrangements . . . These transactions are, in effect, the same as simulated/synthetic loans except that physical currency is produced . . .
I will be seeking leave to table the memorandum from which I have just quoted.

The loan is described as `synthetic'-that is, artificial. The word `create' is in inverted commas, meaning that no actual United States dollar liability was created at all. In addition, no physical currency is produced. What that all adds up to is that a simulated foreign currency loan option is a sham.

The adoption of the currency swap technique avoids any exchange risk in respect of a simulated foreign currency loan. A technical manual entitled, Foreign Exchange in Practice, relied upon by the bank, provides as follows:
8.5 Currency swaps provide a powerful tool for manipulating cross currency cash flows without creating a net exchange position.
The applications of swaps include:
2) Simulated foreign currency loans.
I now quote from paragraph 8.10, under the heading, `Simulated Foreign Currency Loans':

Currency swaps provide a means of generating liquidity. A borrower may wish to borrow HK$ for 3 months. Perhaps he has no facility in place through which he can access either the local HK$ or euro HK$ money markets. Provided he can borrow another currency, say US$, and enter into a US$/HK$ swap he has the means to generate the HK$ required. Generating liquidity in one currency by borrowing another currency and entering into a currency swap is known as a Simulated Loan.
I am still quoting from the handbook-the handbook from which people learn how to perform these simulated sham loans. An example is given as follows:
Step 1: borrow US$ for 3 months
Step 2: Sell US$ and buy HK$ spot
Buy US$ and sell HK$ 3 months forward
The cash flows are equivalent to borrowing HK$ for 3 months.
Step 2 represents a swap. The borrower has borrowed US$ and swapped them into HK$.

There is nothing sham about this type of transaction. It is perfectly legitimate. The borrower receives actual foreign currency without incurring any exchange risk. As we shall see, this is certainly not what the bank had in mind for its customers.

It is quite clear that the bank had the opportunity of providing an exchange risk free facility to its customers but did not do so. It is equally clear that the bank requires its customers to accept the exchange risk, even if it was a sham. A bank memorandum by Mr J. M. McAnary, dated 28 June 1984 and entitled `Simulated Currency Loans' provided that:

. . . a simulated currency loan enables a borrower to maintain his actual borrowing in one currency (eg AUD) but through a forward exchange contract can `simulate' a liability in another currency (eg CHF)-
that is, Swiss francs-

and effectively obtain the benefit of the lower interest rate of that currency . . . The overall result (in terms of overall cost and foreign currency risk exposure) will normally be the same as an outright borrowing in the other currency involved . . .
I will seek leave to table that memorandum.

The question arises: Why did the bank insist upon customers accepting an exchange risk? A bank memorandum from Corporate Banking Division, dated July 1984 and entitled `Simulated Currency Loans' contains an example. I emphasise to the Senate that I am quoting from internal bank documents that spell out this ethos and the methodology.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they fall off the back of a truck?
—They fell from somewhere. These documents spell out the procedures by which the simulated loans are actually conducted. I quote from this memorandum entitled `Simulated Currency Loans':

SPEECH.PARA: Example of Simulated Currency Borrowing
Customer wishes to `simulate' a Swiss Franc (CHF) borrowing for the equivalent of AUD 1 million for six months. In this example, assumptions for the starting date of the transaction are as follows:
CTB CHF selling rate-
- 6 months forward 1.9311

In effecting a `simulated' borrowing, the customer obtains AUD 1 million net finance by say drawing bills under an acceptance/discount facility for face value of $1,064,603 which provides for discount and bank margin of $64,603 (all up interest cost of 13.1% p.a. on 365 day basis).

I am describing the detailed procedures known as the `Rigg incident', about which the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank wrote to me. I chose not to table this document in the Senate. It was tabled in the Senate by former Senator Stone at the request of Mr Don Sanders, and I have said publicly that it contains palpable falsehoods.

As I am running out of time, I will return to the Rigg incident at the next available opportunity. But in this procedure I am attempting to spell out in precise detail, with all of the documentary evidence for the Australian community at large to examine as its property, the internal bank documents which explain the procedure and which put the procedure in place-a procedure by which it is estimated 1,400 Australians were duped of their businesses by banks in this country. I am doing so, hopefully, in the public interest. I will return to this task of exploring the Rigg incident at the next available adjournment opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean sought leave to table various documents. Is leave granted?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is not granted. I wish to address my remarks to Senator McLean in particular. I think it is fair to say that in the last couple of years Senator McLean has developed quite a considerable expertise in translating a lot of jargon in the commercial banking area into some language that most of us can understand. He has done that in the process of developing what seems, in many respects, to be an elaborate conspiracy theory suggesting that at least one bank has been in the business of forcing people to the wall through depriving them of access to funds and, in general terms, acting in bad faith.

SPEECH.PARA: Those are very serious allegations. As I understand it, until today he has not gone so far as to suggest under cover of privilege that certain persons ought to be prosecuted. Having done that, he has put his allegations into another league altogether. It seems that his fanaticism has taken him to the point where he no longer is terribly concerned about due process. But we in the Senate ought to be particularly vigilant to ensure that fanatics do not rule the day.

I regard as a gross invasion of privacy in many respects the suggestion that one can come in here and, on the basis of the end somehow justifying the means, table documents which might severely prejudice any further inquiry. It certainly shows a cavalier disregard for the proper formalities. Most importantly, it is likely to prejudice a fair trial.

I am not impressed by the fact that Senator McLean chose not to show the documents either to our side of the chamber or, I believe, to the Government side. He has been around long enough to know the rules. On two occasions when he rose to seek leave he proceeded as though it were simply a matter of course that he would be doing certain things. He showed no remorse whatsoever. To me that is evidence of the fact that his judgment has been overtaken by his enthusiasm.

I view the matter very seriously. I do not wish to inhibit him from investigating these matters. It may well be that there is a good deal of substance to some of the allegations, but they are very serious matters. Alleging criminal fraud is not alleging negligence; Senator McLean is suggesting that people ought to be behind bars. If that is his position, he should not grandstand on it; he should bring the matters to the attention of the authorities. If there is sensitive correspondence, which he has very fleetingly shown to me, that consists of legal documentation, it is absolutely impossible for us to make judgments about how significant that might be, let alone how crucial it might be, in justifying the bringing of proceedings. It might also be just as crucial in a judge ruling that it is not possible to obtain a fair trial because of the publicity attached to the allegations.

If Senator McLean is simply allowed to wave documents around in this way, McCarthyism is alive and well in Australia. The Senate should not condone those sorts of efforts to bypass the legal system. I will certainly insist that we continue to deny leave to table documents when they are brought forward in the manner in which these were.

I am not troubled by the fact that in the past some documents have been allowed to be tabled in this manner, and I am in no position to judge how significant they were vis-a-vis the ones that were put forward today. But to make the sorts of serious allegations that Senator McLean has made is in itself something that needs to be scrutinised very carefully indeed. Senator McLean has had a full half-hour to make all sorts of statements and perhaps even unwittingly to denigrate people in the process. He is certainly very enthusiastic about developing a conspiracy theory. He ought to stand back and just think about where he is taking the whole issue.

Out there in the sticks it might be pretty popular stuff to be beating banks around the head. From time to time everyone from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) down seems to have a field day doing it. I have no doubt that Senator McLean thinks that he has developed a lot of mileage out of turning this into a long suit. But that is no excuse for ignoring the proper processes of the law.

When one gets to the point where one is making not just general allegations but specific allegations against particular individuals, one has to tread very carefully indeed. I hope that, as a result of the refusal to grant leave, Senator McLean will think very carefully in the future about just what rules he wants to see applying to the way in which people are treated by the courts and by the Parliament.

The Australian Democrats are the ones who wax eloquent about privacy; they are the ones who will go to the wall on the tax file number; they are the ones screaming and yelling about how people are being downtrodden by big bad government. Yet today we have a classic example of an honourable senator allowing himself to be ruled by the headlines that he can see down the track. I do not accept for one moment that that is the proper way in which allegations ought to be aired. There are very well established procedures in this country. Australia has one of the best legal systems in the world. If Senator McLean is fair dinkum about wanting these matters to be investigated and individuals brought to justice, he ought to proceed in the proper way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston, in your remarks you referred to one term, `fanatic', with the implication that Senator McLean's speech was fanatical. This is unparliamentary in so far as it implies that a senator is mindless or fanatical in his speech in the chamber. I ask you to withdraw that implication with regard to another senator.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I would certainly be grateful for an indication from you as to your ruling. I do not think I stated that his speech was fanatical. However, to the extent that I have transgressed, I withdraw the suggestion. I do maintain that what Senator McLean has been on about for the last couple of years can be characterised as verging on the fanatical. I cannot see how that can possibly give offence. I hope that that accords with your ruling.

—I thank you for your withdrawal and will, in the near future, bring to your attention and the Senate's those precedents that relate to the use of the term `fanatical' in respect of another senator. Senator McLean, are you seeking leave to make a further statement?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am seeking leave to make a statement or explanation or whatever mechanism is available to me to respond to Senator Alston's comment.
—In that case you do not need to seek leave.

—I will make it by way of explanation. First, I will pose a question to all senators and all elected representatives in this country: What on earth are we, as elected representatives, expected to do when constituents approach us and convince us, as they have convinced me, that senior management of banks in this country are committing not only malpractice but also corrupt practices? What am I expected to do with that evidence?
—Have you taken legal advice?

—I have taken a lot of legal advice. It should be apparent to Senator Alston that what I have read into the Hansard is the product of a lot of very expert legal advice. The first step that I took was to approach confidentially the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate)-- Senator Tate-When?
—If the Minister looks into his files, he will see that I wrote him a confidential letter saying that I had serious allegations to make and sought his advice. I did not get a reply.
—When, I said.
—It would be about two years ago. I cannot give a precise date. It was when this process began.
—This process has not been followed up.
—I will say how I followed it up.

—Order! Senator McLean, in making a personal explanation following Senator Alston's speech, you have the right not to debate the matter further but only to state how you have been misrepresented and to correct that.

—I have been misrepresented because it has been suggested to the Senate that I have not been responsible in what I have done. With your permission, Mr Acting Deputy President, I will tell you step by step the responsible steps I have taken. The first was to approach the Minister for Justice confidentially and to say that I would prefer not to raise these matters in the chamber. I then asked a series of questions which confirmed to me progressively that there was a problem. I sought a lot of legal advice on how to approach this matter. I have slowly but surely tabled for the consideration of honourable senators evidence of what I consider to be the corrupt practices. I have supported it by all the evidence that is available to me. It is tabled; it is the property of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: For Senator Alston to tell me that these are serious allegations is pathetic. I know they are serious allegations. I have deliberated over them for two years. I have deliberated over the evidence in support of the allegations for more than two years. I deliberated for months before I even wrote my first memo to the Minister for Justice. I know they are serious allegations. I posed questions and I got answers which suggested to me and others from whom I was taking advice that there was a problem. I started to table the evidence progressively and I have built up that evidence. Along the way, I have twice called for a full Senate inquiry to take this matter out of my hands.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you been to the police?
—I have been to the police.
—But they do not agree with you, is that the trouble?
—Read the Hansard of what I have said in this debate. There is now a lot of it.
—You wish to override them?

—No, I do not wish to override them. I simply wish to have them effective. I have twice called for a full Senate inquiry into this matter. It has twice been defeated by a combined vote of Government and Opposition. I simply ask honourable senators to identify for me those who have gone to the evidence and looked at it. I believe there would not be a handful of senators who have actually gone and read the evidence that I have tabled. But they have all voted, twice.
—Order! Senator McLean, you are going further than referring to where you have been misrepresented. I ask you to complete your remarks.

—I am responding to the allegations that I am a fanatic and that I am irresponsible. I am absolutely committed because I am convinced, and I pose the question again: What am I supposed to do with this evidence? I have taken it to the Minister for Justice. I have tried to get it into the hands of the Federal Police. A lot of it has been there. It is now in my hands and I am doing what I am elected to do: I am using the privileges available to me. I know it is a privilege, and if I am abusing it I challenge now the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank to take me to the Privileges Committee and to have that Committee look at the evidence to see whether I am committed or a fanatic. I am not particularly offended by that expression. I think it just flowed off the tongue. In fact, it does get somewhere near the level of commitment I have and the intensity that one must have in order to convince people in this place that there is a serious problem that should be addressed. I will continue to address it.

SPEECH.PARA: There are avenues for the people whom honourable senators believe I have maligned under privilege to respond to my statement. I ask them to do so if they believe that is appropriate. I ask Senator Alston to do so if he thinks that is appropriate because there is nothing I want more than to have this whole matter in other hands, provided they are responsible hands. It is precisely what I am trying to do, whether they be the hands of the Minister for Justice, the Federal Police, a full Senate inquiry, a Privileges Committee or the courts of the land. That is exactly what I am trying to do and what I have pleaded in this place to have done.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Royal Australian Navy: Personnel Posted to Middle East

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the two-week recess, a press release was issued from Senator MacGibbon's office which made a direct challenge to me in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: It is incumbent on Senator Vallentine to declare that neither she nor any of her supporters sought in any way to influence Australian servicemen posted to the Gulf from performing their duties.
Earlier in the release Senator MacGibbon said:
It is quite proper for a senator to publicly express an opinion on any matter of public importance.
It was quite a different matter, particularly for a member of parliament, to attempt to persuade someone to break the law.

I quite gladly now respond to the challenge from Senator MacGibbon. The truth of the matter is that I had nothing to do with the decision of Terry Jones to leave HMAS Adelaide on Tuesday, 21 August. That is the day he left the ship. That is the day on which he was in Perth for final leave. The ship sailed from Stirling naval base on Wednesday, 22 August. I want to put very clearly on the Senate record the sequence of events which flowed on from there.

Terry Jones phoned me-he was totally unknown to me; I had no idea of his identity-on Sunday, 26 August, to say that he was handing himself to the Royal Australian Navy the following day. That was precisely five days after he had left the ship and four days after it had sailed. He told me about his decision and to me it was very clear that he was committed to taking a decision which was obviously going to cost him quite a lot but that he was convinced that he should not be part of the Australian deployment to the Gulf region. I sounded him out and heard his story from him, and it was left at that. I could have gone to the media immediately. I did not do that because I was concerned that whatever was made public from Terry Jones was in his words. The first long conversation I had with him occurred on Sunday, 26 August. At that stage he was in Coffs Harbour. He had gone by bus across the country to rejoin his family.

He then phoned me again on Tuesday, 28 August, having handed himself in to the Navy the day before. It is very important to note that I did not say anything about this to the media. It was a hot story and, had I had chosen to, I could have. But I respected the fact that this was Terry Jones's decision.

On that morning of Tuesday, 28 August, Terry Jones said, `I want to go public on this issue. Can you help me put out a media statement? Can you arrange some legal advice?', because the Navy had told him that he could have independent legal counsel. I advised him to go away for an hour or so and write down exactly what he wanted to say in the statement. I told him that it was very important for the words to be his, not mine or from my office. Terry Jones went away and subsequently phoned my office in Perth an hour or so later and read the statement that he wanted to put out to the media. I now read it to the Senate. A preliminary parts of the statement was prepared by my office indicating who Terry Jones was and putting it into context. The following parts of the statement are his words:

I am prepared to die to defend my country but not to protect United States oil lines. The largest insult I felt personally in the whole affair was turning on the television last Tuesday night and seeing Mr Bush on the international media refusing to discuss what negotiations were going on (over Iraq) while he was on holidays.

Up until this point I had no intention of jumping ship but after seeing one of the parties responsible for it all on holidays playing golf while committing thousands of young lives including those of Australians-it was enough for me to decide not to be part of the killing, knowing that I might have killed innocent people for nothing.
I am not a coward and I would be prepared to die for my country but I am taking a political stand because this is not our war-we are just following the Americans.
Our ships are inadequately prepared and are designed for anti-submarine warfare which is not a front line defence.
The ship's radar is not completely efficient as aircraft can fly under the radar sweep without detection to fire missiles at the ships.

Our chemical warfare equipment is obsolete and probably dates back to the Vietnam period. Even our instructors expressed doubt about the effectiveness of this equipment in the high temperatures and conditions of the Gulf which was terrible for our morale.
Last week Defence Minister Robert Ray said Navy personnel were not pressured or forced to go to the Gulf. I dispute this comment because the ships crews were not given the option of not going.
I approached my immediate superior and explained my concerns about going to the Gulf and I was told that I would not have the option of leaving.
I am highly concerned about the limited information given to the families of naval personnel because of the rapid deployment which gave us little time for proper preparation or goodbyes.

During naval training, recruits are given religious education and they have the commandment `thou shalt not kill' instilled in them. The Australian Navy is contradicting the belief that the Defence Force is a God believing outfit because they answer the call to America not God.
In addition, if the navy is a defence force why did we commit to the Gulf region at the request of the Americans without UN approval in the first place. That is not defence.
Who gave the Americans and the British the right to impose their ways of life on others and to get Australian's to die for it?

Those are Terry Jones's own words. There has been a lot of community support for Terry Jones. There has been some criticism which he also expected but he has had a great deal of community support around the country from people who question the Australian Government's commitment to the Gulf. He expected action to be taken against him by the Navy for being absent without leave. He has reiterated that to me on several occasions. He now awaits the outcome of the internal hearing which was conducted last week. Tomorrow he will be told whether he faces a court martial or disciplinary action as a result of this internal naval inquiry.

I point out that there is a great dilemma for the Navy in all of this because it used the term `conscientious objector' to apply to another unnamed seaman from the HMAS Success who also refused to go to the Gulf for much the same reasons as Terry Jones. The Navy used the term `conscientious objector'. I refer to an article from the Australian dated 28 August 1990:
A conscientious objector on HMAS Success and two `non-volunteers' on HMAS Adelaide were excused from sailing with the Australian naval contingent to the Gulf.
A further eight seamen did not sail as a result of their `commander's discretion', the navy's director of public information, Commander Paddy Hodgman, said.
We have never had an elaboration from the Navy about that Commander's discretion but it could have covered quite a range of contingencies, such as very ill family members. The article continues:
The Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, told Federal Parliament on Friday-
this was in response to a question I asked-
that one sailor had deserted the Gulf Task Force.

The Minister for Defence ought to know better than to use that word `deserter' because technically-it may come as a surprise to some people-Australia is not at war. War has not been declared. So Terry Jones was absent without leave but he is not a deserter. The article continues:

Senator Ray emphasised in answering a question by the Independent Senator Jo Vallentine that `not one person was forced to go on the ships'. The conscientious objector will not face charges arising from his request to not serve in the Gulf.
This is the unnamed seaman from the HMAS Success. In the article, Commander Hodgman is quoted as saying:
His objection was about the particular operation . . .-
this is where the Navy has got itself into a real dilemma over its use of this term-
Obviously a conscientious objector does not join a volunteer Navy.
The article goes on to quote Commander Hodgman as saying:
He will face no action but would probably want to consider how he felt about remaining in the service.

I take that point. Terry Jones knows that he would be due for some disciplinary action for having gone absent without leave but it is very important to understand that the Navy has given this status of conscientious objector to a seaman from HMAS Success. In the case of Terry Jones the Navy has to be seen as being fair. It has to decide whether or not it will use this definition of conscientious objector. Yesterday, evidently the Navy decided that it would not use that terminology, that it did not acknowledge it.

The Navy cannot have one rule for one person who has objected to go to the Gulf for political reasons and a different rule for another who has objected to go to the Gulf for very similar reasons. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald today states:

Commander Paddy Hodgman . . . said the Navy had no place for volunteer sailors who wish to be conscientious objectors and excused from overseas assignments . . . on the grounds that they were opposed for political reasons.

It is true-and I quote from a story by Tony Hewett in the Sydney Morning Herald today-that the Navy would appear to contradict the previously expressed views of the Minister. This also has widespread implications in the case of Leading Seaman Terry Jones who left the Adelaide because he was opposed to the particular engagement.

It is true historically that the term `conscientious objector' has been associated with those who refused to participate in compulsory military service. So there is a difference between young Australians who refused to serve in Vietnam because they were conscripts and this case of Leading Seaman Terry Jones and the other unnamed seaman who volunteered for service in the Navy.

However, it is important to point out that in the last generation the term `conscientious objector' has come to have a wider meaning and to include individuals in the armed services of various countries who object to particular engagements. In other words, there is a selective conscientious objection to a particular engagement. I want to give two examples.

In South Africa there were many whites-and they are the only ones who are volunteers in the South African armed forces-who refused to do service in black townships in South Africa because they did not want to be used as policemen in their own country and who also refused to do service in Namibia and Angola. Just like Terry Jones, they claimed that they would fight to defend their own country but would not engage in non-defensive military expeditions in other countries.

There is also the example of the British troops in Northern Ireland who refused to do service and claimed conscientious objector status. And they have been granted conscientious objector status. They did not want to be used as policemen in their own country. They could make an objection to their commanding officers that they would prefer not to be engaged in a particular deployment. That has been the more recent use of the term `conscientious objector'.

The Navy cannot have it both ways. It must clear up what it means and it has to be seen to be acting fairly. This unnamed seaman is not going to be charged. Terry Jones is going to be charged. He expected to be, of course, because he did go absent without leave, as I said.

It is also important to note that there are American servicemen who are refusing this deployment and who have appealed for conscientious objector status. One of these is Jeff Paterson, a US marine, and I quote from his statement:

I cannot and will not be a pawn in the US's power play for profits and oil in the Middle east. I will resist my scheduled departure by immediately filing for conscientious objector status and physically refusing to board the plane.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do these people join, if they will not fight for their country?
—They are fighting for their own country, in defence of their own country.
—They want it both ways.
—They are prepared. Senator Boswell is not listening to the comments. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: If I am dragged out into the Saudi desert, I will refuse to fight.
That was from Jeff Paterson, a member of the United States Marines. I quote a statement from Erik Larsen, a lance corporal in the Marine Reserves, who declares:

I will refuse orders to activate me into the regular Marines. I will refuse orders to ship me to Saudi Arabia to defend our polluting, exploitative lifestyle. I will refuse to face another human being with a gas mask covering my face and my M-16 drawn. I declare myself a conscientious objector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't these people realise that before they get in the Navy?
—Of course, there have also been conscientious objectors on the other side of this dispute in Iraq. Mr Acting Deputy President, will you please do something about silencing the interjectors?
—Order! Interjections are disorderly. I ask that Senator Vallentine be heard in silence while giving her speech.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. There have also been conscientious objectors on the other side of this dispute. There have been many Iraqis who have refused to go and fire on their brother Arabs. Some officers refused to take part in the invasion of Kuwait. So it happened on the other side as well. Many of them, unfortunately, were executed. Thank goodness we do not go to quite those lengths. But the fact remains that there is disquiet on all sides of this engagement and the term of selective conscientious objection is one which has to be taken seriously and addressed by the Navy.

SPEECH.PARA: I fear that the Navy may be wishing to make an example of Terry Jones because of the planned continued deployment in the Gulf region. If that is so, I think it would be a great shame because the Navy must be seen to be fair.

I want to say that I will continue to support Terry Jones in this brave, courageous and principled decision of refusing to go to the Gulf. I think he had very good reasons for not going. If Senator Boswell had listened to his statement I think he would see that Terry Jones had thought about it and was very clear about it indeed.

I totally reject the allegations of Senator MacGibbon that I incited anybody to leave the service. I repeat my earlier statement that I feel great sympathy for those who are there engaged in this very dangerous situation in the Gulf as a result of a very bad decision of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

Now I want to move into a slightly different aspect of this Gulf engagement. I refer to a motion that was passed by the Labor Party State Executive of Western Australia at its meeting on 27 August. The motion was moved by Frank Donovan, the member for Morley. He and Ian Alexander, the member for Perth, are two elected representatives of the Labor Party in Western Australia who have had the guts to speak out about this decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is 1.45 p.m. and under orders of the Senate relating to the routine of business, the business under consideration would normally be interrupted at this point. But as the Senate is considering the motion for the adjournment and we cannot proceed to any other business until that question is resolved, the debate on the motion that the Senate do now adjourn will proceed.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I appreciate the opportunity to continue with my remarks. I asked on Tuesday to be put on the adjournment speakers list. Another senator who only asked this morning to be put on the adjournment list spoke before me. If he had used his full time and if you had declared the Senate adjourned, I would not have had the opportunity to speak. I reject any notion that automatically I should be put on the bottom of the speakers list.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to quote from the resolution of the State executive meeting of the Labor Party on Monday, 27 August 1990. It is important that I quote the whole resolution, because to quote selectively from it might give an impression that is not the total view that was intended by the mover of the motion. The motion, which is headed, `Crisis in the Middle East', reads:

That the State Executive, in asserting that the invocation of Article 51 of the UN Charter allowing nations to aid others in case of attack is an insufficient and dangerous justification for military enforcement of the UN Security Council trade embargo,
(1) condemns unequivocally the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the taking hostage of foreign nationals to use as human shields;

(2) expresses its strong concern about the manner in which the Federal Government decision to commit naval forces to the Persian Gulf was made without consultation with the full Cabinet, the FPLP Caucus or the Leader of the Opposition;

(3) insists that Australia's present commitment of three warships not be committed to any military action beyond the provisions of UN 665 (1990), and that no further military commitment to the Middle East of any kind be considered until and unless military command of all forces is in the exclusive hands of the UN Military Staff Committee under Article 47 of the UN Charter; and

(4) in the event of any military action by any element of the multinational force before the application of Article 47 and beyond the provisions of UN resolution 665 (1990), calls upon the Federal Government to rescind its present and any subsequent decisions to commit Australian military forces to the Middle East.

I commend Frank Donovan for putting forward that motion and for the strong position that he and Ian Alexander have taken. I do not know whether other members of the Labor Party-elected representatives in other States-have taken a similar strong stand but I do applaud them for doing so. I know that in Caucus and in private many members of the Left in particular have expressed angst about this particular decision. But I do wish that they would speak out about this decision of the Prime Minister as they are prepared to speak out on privatisation and other issues. They are prepared to do battle with the Prime Minister and senior Ministers on some issues but I cannot understand the deafening silence on this one.

It was also agreed at the Caucus meeting that there would be full consultation before any further decision was made for extra deployment in the Gulf region. Yet we heard the Minister for Defence in this chamber on Tuesday admit that, yes, a small force of technical support people had gone to the Gulf region and that, yes, a hospital team had also gone to the Gulf region. So what we are seeing is a gradual escalation of the Australian contribution, again without consultation.

In fact, I believe that the Minister's office did not even have notice or consultation, although the Minister says that he was consulted. I have had this on authority from people who telephoned his office to ask about this particular deployment of ground support in the Gulf region. People volunteered to a journalist who phoned up, `Yes, we know all about everything. We are up to date with everything. We have had a full briefing. What is it you want to know?'. When the journalist asked the question about this ground support deployment there was a stunned silence at the other end of the telephone line.

At the same time, the Prime Minister's office has said that this is purely administrative so there was no political decision involved. That is tantamount to saying that there had been no consultation. We have to get these matters cleared up. We have to ask, `What will be next? Will there be further deployment?'. I asked a question of the Minister on Tuesday and I am satisfied with his answer as of Tuesday. But it seems that that same question would need to be asked at every moment of every day, because we have no confirmation and I do not trust any assurance that has been given about Australia's deployment to the Middle East not being increased.

At the same time we have George Bush seeking ground support from the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation and other allied countries. He is talking about a permanent force in the Gulf region to maintain oil supplies for the West. It has often been said that the first casualty of war is truth. Perhaps the same could be said of preparations for war. I do not like the way that the gradual escalation of Australian forces is continuing in that direction. I think it is a very dangerous situation for Australia to have got itself into.

I do not see that the Prime Minister is about to withdraw those forces from the Gulf because the President of the United States would not like it. It would seem as though Australia was losing face in the international community. But it is far from the rest of the world against the Iraqi forces. Although the Soviet Union has supported the economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations (UN) -which I would also support, with the exception of sanctions in regard to humanitarian and medical aid-it has stopped short of committing any military force to the region. That is what President Bush hoped to get out of Mikhail Gorbachev and he failed to do so. So we cannot say that it is the rest of the world militarily lined up against Saddam Hussein. Perhaps a saving grace in all of this is that we may stop short of a war in the Middle East. There is room for negotiation and for consultation, and that is what we need to be engaging in.

I will not repeat my original opposition to the Australian deployment. I think that is well known, United Nations resolution 665 notwithstanding. I believe that the UN Security Council was manipulated and that this was an attempt after the event to secure legitimacy for what had already happened. Resolution 665 is not a call to arms. The emphasis is still on diplomacy and that is the way we should be going.

There is a great opportunity for Australia to suggest a mediated settlement to this dispute. If Australia under the guidance of our Foreign Minister could get the Cambodian four warring factions together to work out a mediated settlement under the guidelines of the UN and under UN monitoring-and he deserves full congratulations for having done that, as does our Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Mr Mike Costello in particular-I challenge the Foreign Minister to put forward an Australian plan which would involve a negotiated settlement between the Arab League and the United Nations: for the Arab League and the UN to supervise the Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait and to monitor the return of an elected government in Kuwait.

I do not think that we particularly want to see the return of the petroleum kings, the emirs who do not care much about spreading or sharing their enormous wealth with their subjects. Of course, there is no illusion that Kuwait was any kind of democracy, so we cannot talk about that. But I believe that Australia could put forward a plan for the Arab League and the United Nations to work together towards a mediated settlement, to supervise the Iraqi withdrawal and to monitor the return of an elected government in Kuwait.

There is far too much at risk in either the war scenario or the permanent forces scenario in the Gulf to maintain the oil lines. Neither scenario will settle the longstanding and deeply felt disputes in the region. A negotiated settlement is indeed the only longstanding settlement which will be satisfactory on a global and permanent basis. I would like to quote Richard Leaver on this first major postwar dispute and its handling. This is the first time that there has been a massive international crisis since the Cold War could be considered over. I quote from Richard Leaver writing in the Australian Financial Review of 6 September 1990:
The fact remains that the first crisis of the post Cold War era is essentially being `solved' through the sort of heavy unilateralism that was a primary characteristic of the Cold War era.
The heritage of our Labor Government is made of better stuff. It includes a distinguished effort by Evatt to redress inequalities of power within the UN.
It is therefore particularly disappointing that the Hawke Government has chosen `good American citizenship' in preference to the `good international citizenship' . . .
That is what we should be espousing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to congratulate Senator Vallentine on her speech today. It was one I was very disappointed in. She gave great sympathy to a person who I consider ratted on his mates, walked out on his friends-Terry Jones. Yet she spent the first 15 minutes of her contribution praising him and making excuses for him. I am absolutely disgusted that she would so waste the time of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The people I have sympathy for are the 500 people outside this House who are trying to maintain their lives. I refer to the timber workers of this nation who have been betrayed by this Government, which will not give them a go and will not allow them to continue to earn their livelihoods. Those are the people that I have sympathy for. Those people have come here to plead with the Government and to demonstrate that they need their livelihoods. This is the spirit of free enterprise working. I congratulate them on their orderly and progressive proposal to this Parliament. The way they have conducted themselves has been beyond reproach. The trucks are out there lined up and the drivers are pleading with this Parliament, with the representatives of the people, to allow them to make a decent honest living.

Today I want to address a problem that arises in the aftermath of some of the World Heritage areas decisions and which in the north Queensland area has affected the brothers of the people demonstrating outside. What do we say to a group of small businessmen who have lost hundreds of thousands of dollars by investing in the footsteps of the Federal Government? What do we say to a community whose survival depends on the Government's honouring its commitment to see it safely through a time of great and traumatic change directly caused by an Act of Parliament? Finally, what do we say to the people of Ravenshoe who were told time and again that no-one would be disadvantaged by World Heritage listing?

The compensation package required as a result of World Heritage listing of Queensland's wet tropics has been nothing more than a showbag of toys, tricks and gimmicks designed to give temporary short term relief from the hardships imposed by World Heritage listing. This $75m package was full of promises of plantations, tourism and plenty of work for all. In reality, it has provided some short term local council work. I see that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia (Senator Collins) has now entered the chamber and I welcome his participation in this debate. This situation has resulted in people having to do menial work, tidying up the streets, and painting and cleaning toilets, because that is all the work that is offered.

The most significant single plank of the compensation package was the financial assistance to be rendered to the Ravens- hoe mill. The Commonwealth agreed to pay millions of dollars to the mill to enable it to be retooled to cope with non-rainforest timbers, thus ensuring its continued viability. The Ravenshoe mill has been the economic focal point of the town and the town's biggest employer. Not only has it provided steady employment for 48 people, but the retooling program has given a much needed boost to the fortunes of Ravenshoe's small businesses, which were suffering as a result of World Heritage listing.

The town was knocked for six by the cessation of logging. The social and economic disruptions were severe. The only thing that kept hope alive in Ravenshoe was the future of the Associated Plywoods Sales Pty Ltd (APS) timber mill, as assured by the Government. `Securing the future of Ravenshoe' was how the then Minister, Senator Richardson, described it in a statement in April 1988. However, if all our futures were dependent on the ability of the Minister to follow through on his pledges, we would be paying very high life insurance premiums. No wonder pensioners are concerned and suspicious when they are told by the same Minister that no-one will be worse off under Budget changes.

In north Queensland the current situation is that the Ravenshoe mill is in the hands of receivers and has been since April of this year. The mill owes local townspeople $220,000, which is a considerable amount of money for a small town. It owes Far North Queensland some $500,000 overall. In addition, the mill is indebted to the Westpac Banking Corporation for an unspecified amount. The mill has also received significant funding from the Commonwealth. At the time of the receivership, the Commonwealth had provided approximately $7.5m in loan and subsidy assistance. A sum of $4.5m was for an interest-free loan, repayable over 10 years. This loan was provided to the company on 30 June 1988. The sum of an additional $2.125m in the form of a grant was provided to the company in July 1989. That is a significant grant, as I think the Minister would agree. At Question Time I asked the Minister to give us some information on this matter. He has agreed to do so and I thank him for that.

Mr Deputy President, who would have thought that the company would be put in the hands of a receiver less than 12 months after a government grant of $2m. What has happened since the company received the Government loans and the subsidies? The only thing we know for sure is that the people of Ravenshoe are even worse off now than before the agreement was reached between the Government and the company, Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd.

It all seemed such a good idea at the time: Price Waterhouse checked out the company and said it was indeed financially viable; the Commonwealth went ahead in a great fanfare of media releases and back patting and spent millions on this particular project. In reality, the Federal Labor Government wrote a couple of cheques as the easiest way to absolve itself from guilt over the tremendous negative social and economic impact of World Heritage listing on towns like Ravenshoe.

The then Minister, Senator Richardson, did a Pontius Pilot, washing his hands of the people of Ravenshoe. But this washing of hands for something that was going dreadfully wrong at the mill was too premature, even though Price Waterhouse had checked the company out.

With the Government money the mill started its retooling and bought heavily from local businesses. They ranged from earth moving, transport, engineering, electrical and plumbing businesses to hotels and motels. They believed the Minister when he said that no-one would be disadvantaged under World Heritage listing. They were prepared to extend credit to the Associated Plywoods Sales sawmill during the period of retooling knowing that the Federal Government had thoroughly investigated the project and made an ongoing financial commitment to its future.

Now these same people, guilty only of showing faith in their government and taking the commitment of a Minister seriously, are carrying significant debts at a time of high bank interest rates. Some businesses will be forced to close. Townspeople report that there has been an increase in unemployment, vandalism, drug abuse and child abuse as the pressures build up on their families.

I cannot put it more plainly, Mr Deputy President: the Government and the Minister at the table, Senator Collins, as the Minister responsible for the wet tropics, owe them for disrupting their lives by World Heritage listing the forests that they have lived in and worked in for generations. The Government owes them for replacing the dignity of work with the indignity of welfare handouts. And now the Government also owes them for not keeping a proper eye on a multimillion dollar investment that was supposed to save a whole town. All taxpayers in Australia have the right to know what happened to their money that was poured into this venture. Some $7.5m has gone down the chute. The venture has never given anyone any degree of work or continued prosperity as it was supposed to do.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) is fond of bank bashing, saying that the banks lent money too readily to too many risky ventures without proper analysis and follow-up. The case of Ravenshoe Mill is a classic example of the Government being guilty of the same thing. There was clearly a lack of audited management, a lack of checks and balances, to ensure the proper use and distribution of millions of taxpayers' dollars.

According to answers given to me in Estimates committee hearings, it was not until the first week in April this year that the Department was alerted to the fact that there were problems with the whole corporate structure, as one officer put it. There are a number of questions that must be answered if the Government is to be accountable on this matter, for $7.5m is a lot of money.

Has it been spent according to the terms of the agreement between APS and the Government-that is, for retooling and subsidy payments relating to the employment of timber workers? If not, where has it gone? To the parent company in New South Wales, for instance? What checks and balances were in place to ensure that this amount of taxpayers' money was spent in a financially responsible way and in line with the terms of the agreement made by this Government?

The Government has already admitted that it has no legal obligation to bail out the unsecured Ravenshoe creditors of the APS mill, but is it also a fact that the Government itself has had little chance of recouping any of the $7.5 million it gave to the mill? Is it not also true that the first secured creditor, Westpac, which called in the receivers, is also unlikely to recoup all its money?

It is also pertinent to ask whether the Sydney parent company, Scotswood Streets Ltd, was fully investigated prior to the multimillion dollar agreement. In addition, there is the matter of the proceeds from two auctions in December last year and as late as June of this year. Prime rainforest timber valued at some $200,000 was sold at these auctions. I ask the Minister to give me an assurance that these moneys did not disappear south but were put towards the Ravenshoe mill operators and/or its creditors.
I call on the Minister, Ros Kelly --

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Mrs Kelly, please.

—I call on the Minister, Mrs Ros Kelly, through her representative in this place, Senator Collins, to make public the results of her departmental investigation into this financial catastrophe, and to explain, if she can, why the Government knew too little and too late about the goings on of a company that had just received $7.5 million of taxpayers' money. The taxpayer deserves to know if his money has been misappropriated and if charges are to be laid as a result.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am sure that the people of Ravenshoe do not need to be reminded of all the empty promises made to them by the politicians among the Labor Party, I think the Government needs to be reminded. Firstly, there was the famous or now infamous statement by Senator Richardson, then Minister for the Environment, that no-one would be disadvantaged by World Heritage listing.

Subsequent to the company being placed in receivership, the good people of Ravenshoe tried to follow up this promise. They contacted a number of elected representatives explaining the difficulties being caused by the sudden collapse of the mill company. The reply was deafeningly quiet from State and Federal Ministers. I am sure that Bill Eaton, the local State member, did his best. The reply that really took the cake was a telephone call in which the Queensland Treasurer and member for Cairns, Keith Delacy, thanked the people concerned for their low key approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell, I would ask you to use the proper form of address for members of this place and other Houses.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Still trusting the men from the Government who were there to help them, the business people of Ravenshoe continued their low key approach as it was continually stressed to them that this would keep the Government on side and they desperately needed the Government on side.

SPEECH.PARA: The rewards did not appear to be forthcoming however. The mill receiver-manager, Mr Greg Kelly, of Price Waterhouse was reported in the Australian dated 17 May as saying that the Ravenshoe business community would probably be the last in line to be repaid once a buyer for the operation was found. Furthermore, the article says that Mr Kelly said he had received a commitment from the office of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, that Federal assistance for the APS operation would continue. However, the last paragraph states:
A spokesman for Ms Kelly said yesterday the Federal Government would wait for the outcome of any sale negotiations before considering further assistance.

If the people of Ravenshoe are confused, one could not blame them. They are people that have made a living out of cutting trees, not understanding ministerial doubletalk. The Government was making all sorts of ad hoc statements with no thought to the trauma and confusion it was causing the Ravenshoe community and its business plans. The new Minister has more recently chimed in with, and I quote:

We have a legal obligation to the existing mill. That is a priority-to keep it open. I shall look into it and see if the business people can be paid. I am very sympathetic to their cause. The first priority is to protect the jobs in the town and I will do whatever is necessary to do that.

That was reported in the Cairns Post of 14 June 1990. Then a couple of months later there were two conflicting reports. The Tableland Express, a north Queensland paper, reported in its 11 August edition that the member for Kennedy said that `the community's best prospect was the early sale of the APS sawmill, which explained why Ros Kelly had her Department negotiating with the receiver-manager on conditions for temporary assistance to keep the sawmill operating pending its sale'. On the same date the Courier Mail reported:

The Federal Environment Minister, Mrs Kelly, in Cairns to announce a new management authority for the World Heritage area, said yesterday no further funding would be given to the north Queensland town's Associated Plywoods Sales Timber Mill or its creditors.

So there are two directly conflicting statements. I ask the Minister to tell the House today the real story. Where is the Government going on this? The Government has behaved in a most amateur and cavalier fashion towards the people of Ravenshoe. I call on Senator Collins to answer the questions I have raised so that we can bring some normality back to the debate and to the lives of the Ravenshoe people. I call on the Government to honour its pledge and recommit itself to the future of Ravenshoe, to a future that does not depend on social welfare but on the dignity of the worker.

I remind Senator Collins that the people being affected up there are unionists; they are his grassroots. They are not small business people or farmers; they are timber workers in the main; they are people that always support the Labor Party. They are members of the Australian Workers Union and are coming to us for help when they should be turning to the Government members. Those are the people they elect to parliament. They are the people they pay $160 a year to. They are the people they rely on. I ask the Government to look after their interests.

The Government is fully aware of an offer to purchase the mill since the retooling. A Government commitment is still incomplete. The potential buyers have asked that the Government maintain the level of funding as per its original agreement with the previous company. According to these interested buyers, the mill requires at least another $750,000 to buy new equipment just to raise the capacity of the timber mill to some 25,000 cubic metres and make it viable. Millions more are required to finish the job properly as promised by the Federal Government. It appears that the retooling done so far has not been appropriate or sufficient.

If the Government were to honour its original funding agreement, which involves the balance of the $13m set aside, the mill could continue operating and become a viable enterprise. It does not require the Government to fork out any additional money than has already been set aside for this project. The potential purchasers merely want the Government to continue its original arrangement. Such an arrangement would ensure that the mill and its assets were not split up for a bank fire sale. It would ensure that the mill would continue to provide employment and business for the small business people in Ravenshoe and the local small business people would have a chance to recoup some of the losses suffered as a result of the collapse of the original company.

I do not think that the interested buyer's request for the Government to honour its original funding commitment is unreasonable, as long as some financial checks are carried out. I ask the Minister to give these matters that I have raised urgent consideration.

I know that Senator Collins and all members of the Government are concerned about this. But it seems that there have been insufficient checks and balances as to how the money has been handed out. But that, I say to Senator Collins, who I hope will respond, is not the fault of the timber growers, the timber workers or the small business people; it is the Government's fault for not looking after taxpayers' money.

I urge the Government not to take the stick out on the people that are innocent. They trusted the Government's commitment of $7.5m by way of compensation for the World Heritage area. It is not their fault that the Government did not provide sufficient checks on where that $7.5m was going. On their behalf I ask the Government to admit its mistakes, to pay for them itself, and not pass its sins onto the timber workers and the small business people of Ravenshoe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take just a few minutes of the Senate's time to support what Senator Boswell has said. I am sure that the Government understands as well the trauma that has been caused to people who, believing in all good faith that the mill was being supported, gave it credit and then found to their dismay that the mill had gone into receivership.

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware, as I am sure the Government is, that there is no legal compulsion once the mill goes into receivership for any payments to be made. As I say, I am aware that the Government has no legal compulsion to make payments, but I do ask the Minister and the Government to consider an ex gratia payment from the funds which are already available and unexpended for World Heritage compensation. I do not want to take the matter any further at this stage, Mr Deputy President, but simply add my plea to Senator Collins and the Government to make some special allowance for the people who in this instance have lost so much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: — I will respond briefly, much to the disgust of the Government Whip, and try not to detain the Senate long because Estimates committees are to meet shortly. However, there is one thing I want to make clear. I am indeed the Minister responsible for advising the Prime Minister on Northern Australia but that is not an executive responsibility I have to this Parliament, which Senator Boswell understands.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply make that point because the Minister in this place who is responsible for this issue is Senator Richardson. I have spoken to Senator Richardson in accordance with the undertakings which I gave Senator Boswell this morning and Senator Richardson will, in fact, respond in the Senate at a later stage.

I have been provided with some information by the Minister responsible-that is, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly-which I think is important to put on the record in response. The circumstances are: the holding company, Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd, which owns the Associated Plywoods Sales Pty Ltd sawmill, is in financial difficulties and that cannot be overstated.

A receiver-manager was appointed for the company in April 1990. The financial difficulties were caused by a cash flow in the holding company elsewhere and in fact are not due at all to the World Heritage listing. Indeed I see Opposition senators nodding in agreement that that is understood at this stage. I am not suggesting for one minute that that detracts from the difficult situation that the business people of Ravenshoe are facing.

The APS sawmill at Ravenshoe in north Queensland was affected by the listing of the wet tropics of north Queensland as a World Heritage area in 1988. A 10-year, $8m-that is, net present value- assistance agreement was signed on 30 June 1988 between the Commonwealth and the holding company that owns the sawmill to retool it to process plantation timber. The assistance was provided under the structural adjustment package established to mitigate the impact of the World Heritage listing in accordance with undertakings that were given by the Government.

The receiver-manager, at his meeting with the Minister on 19 June this year, advised that the sawmill was continuing operations for the foreseeable future and that the business had been advertised for sale as a going concern, as Senator Boswell has said.

The Minister then decided that the best way to assist the community at Ravenshoe was to negotiate temporary assistance to keep the sawmill operating until it was sold. The Minister invited the receiver-manager to negotiate for temporary assistance pending the sale of the APS sawmill as a going concern.

The Ravenshoe community has received significant support from the Commonwealth Government to mitigate the impact of World Heritage listing. A number of businesses in Ravenshoe have in fact received income from the sawmill during its retooling phase and the sawmill's work force expanded during this year.

Furthermore, approximately $1.2m in addition to that $8m package, has been paid in compensation, directly to Ravenshoe businesses that have been directly and substantially affected by the World Heritage listing. At least 20 retrenched timber industry workers in Ravenshoe have received assistance from the Commonwealth Government under the wet tropics structural adjustment package.

In these circumstances the Minister considers that it would be inappropriate for the Commonwealth Government to intervene in what has been and is acknowledged to have been a commercial failure by the holding company in its various operations in the State of New South Wales. The best prospect for the future of the Ravenshoe community is for the early sale of the mill. There have been five bids to acquire the mill. In respect of what is a very serious point about the money that is owed to local businesses as a result of the failure of the mill, all I can say is that there are a wide number of figures being debated as to what this is. People in Ravenshoe are claiming that they are owed $500,000. The figure of $250,000 was mentioned in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —To a couple of different companies.

—Sure, but there is a wide variation in the figures. In fact, I know that advice has been received that the actual figure is probably as low as $150,000. But these debts occurred because of the commercial failure of the holding company in its operations in New South Wales.
—No-one is questioning that.

—No, no-one is questioning that, but it is important to say it again for the simple reason that Senator Boswell said again and again during his speech that somehow or other, and the inference is always there, the failure of the sawmill was a direct result of the World Heritage listing. It was not.
—I suggest that you didn't monitor it.

—I am glad that that has been nailed down and acknowledged by the Opposition. It was in fact due to the commercial failing of the holding company that owned the sawmill in respect of its operations in another State. The fact is that the debts occurred because of this failure and were not due to World Heritage listing. They are a matter for resolution, as they would be under any other circumstances, between the unsecured creditors and the receiver-manager of the sawmill.

SPEECH.PARA: On 25 June this year the Minister advised unsecured creditors that they were unlikely to receive their funds until Westpac had recovered its debt. Senator Boswell has raised that point. The Minister said that the Government's first priority was to try to assist the sawmill to continue operating, as I have already said. Nevertheless, the Minister has said that if this fails the Government will do the very best it can to look at ways that the Commonwealth can further assist the businesses and residents of Ravenshoe. That undertaking has been given.

I would like to conclude by saying that I have spoken to Senator Richardson about this. He has given me an assurance that he will respond further to the concerns raised by Senator Boswell. However, I want to make one final point: I am a member of the Wet Tropics Council, as Senator Boswell has said, that will oversight the operations of that magnificent area. Having had the opportunity for the first time in years to visit that area, although I have been there before, I can say with absolute conviction that in terms of the magnificent asset that those tropical rainforests of north Queensland are-I say this even as a Territorian-it is some of the most spectacularly beautiful country in Australia.

Ian McLachlan-I cannot use his title because I do not know what it is; I am not familiar with the seats in the other place, but he is a member of the other House-stated in a public speech the other day, and I am glad that people like Mr McLachlan are prepared to come out and be honest about it, what the Opposition's policy is on sustainable development. SPEECH.PARA: The reason I make this point is that --

Senator Boswell knows full well that before I came into politics I spent eight years of my life as a researcher with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation working in Kakadu National Park.
